http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value:
Places are the individual nodes of our cable networks. They are either tagged by this page, or one of the following place designations: Place 0-299, Place 300-599, Place 600-899, Place 900-1199, Place 1200-1499, and Place 1500-1799.
To create a page for a new cable, see the reference page for places.

Sumay, once a thriving Chamorro town, is today a site of displacement and dispossession. The small village was located on the shores of Apra Harbor, and shielded from foreign circulations in part by its coral reef. Pirates and privateers that wanted to avoid the Spanish, who ruled the island from the sixteenth to the nineteenth century, took refuge in the harbor and bartered with local Chamorros. Although the Spanish eventually built forts to secure the area, in 1898 the Americans sailed easily into the harbor and took Guam with no struggle. Under American rule, Sumay changed drastically. The United States established a Marine Corps Aircraft Squadron there. Pan American Airways used the area as a landing for its China Clipper, and subsequently built the first hotel on Guam nearby. The Commercial Pacific Cable Company laid their transpacific cable to Sumay's shores. These businesses played a large role in the economic prosperity of the village, and many villagers worked at the cable station. But when the Japanese attacked the island in 1941, the town's entire population was evacuated. Even after the United States reclaimed Guam, the villagers were not allowed back to their land. Instead, the harbor became home to one the most important naval bases in the Pacific. The only remainders of the community and cable hub are ruins, now overgrown by the jungle, and a small cemetery that villagers are permitted to visit once a year.
This cable was extended between Guam and Japan's Bonin Islands in 1906. It connected the Commercial Pacific Cable's line from the United States all the way to Asia.
This cable, originally laid by the German-Netherlands Telegraph Company, was diverted by the Japanese to Palau in 1942.

Strung between Hawai'i and California in 1902, and extending onward to Guam, Japan, and the Philippines in the years after, the Commercial Pacific Cable was the first "American" transpacific link. Secretly, however, it was owned in part by the British Eastern Telegraph company, a trade off the cable layers had to give up in order to gain access to lucrative Chinese markets.

About four hours by plane from Tokyo, Manila, and Seoul, five hours from Taipei and Hong Kong, and seven hours from Honolulu (with direct flights from all of these cities), Guam is a point of interconnection between East Asian and American transportation routes. I arrive on the flight from Hawai‘i at A.B. Won Pat International Airport on a hot summer afternoon, where I am met by a distant relative, the son of my mother’s brother’s wife’s cousin (everyone seems to have a distant connection to Guam). While guiding me on a tour of Tumon Bay, a waterfront lined with towering, extravagant hotels, upscale designer stores, and seedy strip clubs, he asks me what brings me to the island since “it’s not on the way anywhere.” 

As I describe the cable networks that position Guam as a center for Pacific Internet traffic, I think about how this island – home to approximately 180,000 residents – is actually on the way to a number of places. It is a temporary destination for Japanese and Korean tourists, Micronesian islanders looking for an education or a job, Americans stopping for a tour on one of the two military bases, and travelers on a layover between cities. Guam is a meeting point, a site of exchange at which different kinds of flows do not simply terminate, but are interconnected.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: Telegraph Bay, Pok Fu Lam, Hong Kong

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Barty-King: from here they connected to Eastern Extension office at Marine Hour – on the site occupied by Old Mercury House in 1979.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In nineteenth-century Hong Kong, a barrage of undersea cables – from Singapore, Shanghai, Fuzhou, Manila, Labuan, and Macau – landed at Telegraph Bay. From here, cables wound inland across the island’s northern shore, through the city center to the busy Eastern Extension cable office. The daily work of cablemen at “Electra House,” as it was called, was eventful. Traffic was re-directed from one network to another, messages linked local commerce into a global economy, and important political information was relayed about British-Chinese relations. Yet as they sustained the network, cablemen also worried about sustaining themselves. They were concerned about finding healthy food (one worried that local vegetables were not clean enough to eat) and about catching the plague (another remarked that “Hong Kong would not be Hong Kong if we didn’t have an epidemic of something every year”). And leading up to World War II, a cableman recounted, “Life in Hong Kong has been subject to rude jolts during recent years… we had quite a few delightful moments dealing with traffic which poured in for places which had been 'interrupted by bomb.'” Not long after, station life would be interrupted completely when the Japanese took over the island. Today the work of Hong Kong’s cablemen has moved to the island’s southern shore, but Telegraph Bay remains a center of information exchange. It is now the location of the expansive Cyberport, a “creative digital community” built to foster technology development.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: Vladivostok - Nagasaki - Shanghai - Amoy - Hong Kong

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Heralded as the great event of the year, the completion of this Russian-Japanese-Chinese link in 1871 brought British interests in China into “instantaneous communication with London” through a much-needed secondary route. News of the project inspired a demonstration of the technology for a pair of Canton officials. As British administrators report, both “showed interest and appreciation; and we hope their experience may tend to remove the prejudice with which electricity, like every other novelty, has been hitherto regarded in China.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1880-?; Telcon, Eastern Extension Australasia China Telegraph Company

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: As the first undersea cable to the Philippines, the Eastern Extension’s 1880 project extended from Hong Kong to Boliano (and onwards overland for 160 miles to Manila). The project was financed by the Spanish government, in part by granting the British company tax exempt status and a monopoly over the region. This arrangement led to several years of legal debate after America seized the Philippines and refused to comply with the Spanish remuneration agreement.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1883-?; Telcon; Eastern Extension Australasia China Telegraph Company; Scotia System 471 + 449 nm (1888/Barty-King 96, but may be typo)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The first British cable laid in China in over twelve years, the link between Hong Kong and Shanghai laid in 1883 by way of Foochow was a daring leap forward for the British industry, made in defiance of official Chinese wishes and the Danish monopoly on communications to Shanghai. The British were confident in both their authority to act and the technical properties of the cable. Commentators note, “is said to be one of the best yet made, and it has very remarkable electrical conductrosity” [sic].

When laying this system in 1871, the Telegraph Construction and Maintenance Company encountered bad weather which made it "necessary to cut and buoy the cable in 700 fathoms of water." Nonetheless, the company managed to complete the link on June 11, a mere twenty-four hours after its deadline.

This French-subsidized, British laid line of 1884 connected what was then called Tonquin to the central communications hub in Hong Kong. The project followed closely after France’s declaration to establish Tonquin, its newest “frontier,” as a French protectorate.

This cable, laid by the British Eastern Extension Australasia China Telegraph Co. in 1884, connected British Hong Kong and Portuguese Macau. The Portuguese government paid Britain a yearly subsidy of £500 for the service. Although China never signed the Convention for the Protection of Submarine Telegraph Cables negotiated that year, its protections were nevertheless afforded to the Hong Kong – Macau line, thanks to the exceptional status of the colonial territories.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1894-?; Telcon; Eastern Extension, Australasia China Telegraph Co; Scotia (see AtlanticCable.com)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: An 1894 article about the cable in The Singapore Free Press and Mercantile Advertiser observes that this system, a duplicate route between Singapore and Hong Kong, "is a work almost of supererogation, certainly one not required or justified by the existing traffic." At that point a single cable could still carry all of the traffic to and from China. Instead, the aim was "to give greater assurance and security to communication between India and Europe and between [Singapore] and China." By connecting the main naval base at Hong Kong with the other colonies (and stopping only on British territory), they predicted that the new cable would "materially increase the security of British interests in the Far East."

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article/singfreepressb18940212.2.15.aspx

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Completed in 1913 in tandem with the Penang-Colombo link, the project was part of a larger Eastern Extension Telegraph Company initiative to improve the ease of transmission for messages sent across the British colonies.

The first transpacific cable terminated in Southport, a small coastal town not far from Brisbane, the capital of Queensland, Australia. In 1901, prior to the cable's arrival, the town's population was a mere 1230 people. From Southport, traffic was then routed by land to Sydney, but this terrestrial connection was one of the least stable segments of the entire transpacific cable. Aboriginal inhabitants regularly cut down the line. Despite the fickle land-line, this cable station operated for sixty years, closing in July 1962. Even after it stopped transmitting international messages, the cable station continued to have a legacy in the beach town. In the 1980s, when the buildings were under threat of demolition, residents spearheaded a campaign to save them. The cable station was renovated, restored, and moved to become the Music Department of the nearby Southport School. Today a park, a street, and an apartment building have all been named after the area's former transpacific cable.
The Pacific Cable Board's landline between Southport and Sydney was so unreliable that, when the system was upgraded in 1923, it was replaced by a submarine cable.

Sanford Fleming and the Canadian Government mobilized arguments about security to establish the first transpacific cable system in 1902, creating a foundational route for all north-south Pacific traffic. This system mastered the scale of the globe: the Pacific Cable Board line between Bamfield, Canada and Fanning Island was then the longest undersea cable in the world. This system also required new expenditures for infrastructure and planning. A new 8,000 ton ship, the Colonia, had to be constructed specifically for the line.

You have landed on the shores of Okinawa Island, just one island in an archipelago about 300 miles south of the rest of Japan and only 200 miles northeast of Taiwan. Geographically and politically separated from the other Japanese islands, Okinawa remained more or less self-governing until the Meiji Restoration, when it became a target for Japan’s expansionist aims. After winning the Sino-Japanese War in 1895, Japan immediately began laying cables to its colonial territories, including one that linked to Taiwan via Okinawa. For this endeavor, Japan even built its own cable ship, the Okinawa Maru. Following the massive destruction of World War II, Okinawa remained a cable hub, but the station was located far from the island's commercial center, perceived as more vulnerable to attack. Unlike the expansionist telegraph network, the coaxial and fiber-optic projects were collaborative international endeavors. Kokusai Denshin Denwa, Japan’s telecommunications company, partnered with American, Filipino, Chinese, and Korean companies to make Okinawa a stop on numerous transoceanic networks. Several cables continue to have a life even after they became obsolete, now carrying geophysical observations rather than telephone calls.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Tomishirominami High School Students, “The Sea in Gushikami,” Sea in Okinawa, accessed August 18, 2013, http://www.okiu.ac.jp/Language/contest/01/01/gushikami.htm.

“International Workshop on the Scientific Use of Submarine Cables,” Past Conferences – International Conferences with EM components, MTNet, accessed August 18, 2013, http://mtnet.dias.ie/conferences/1997/cables97.txt.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Okinawa - Luzon - Hong Kong cable, like others of the 1970s, was given an acronym that combined the first letters of the places that were connected: OLUHO. It was not until the fiber-optic period and the break-up of the consortium system that this naming practice began to shift to use more symbolic and less descriptive terms.

A coaxial cable laid in 1979, OKITAI comprised part of the telephone infrastructure between Japan and Taiwan for almost twenty years. It was donated to the Ocean Research Institute of the University of Tokyo in 1998, where it now serves as an instrument to measure the Kuroshio current, among other oceanic phenomena.

After twelve years of service this coaxial cable was made obsolete by advances in fiber optics and was subsequently donated to the University of Tokyo’s Earthquake Research Institute. No longer used for telephone calls, it enjoys a lively afterlife as an early warning sensor for seismic activity and instrument for measuring the magnetic fields of the Earth’s mantle.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The cost of even a short coaxial system, such at this link between Okinawa and Miyazaki laid in 1977, was not trivial. The cable required over $7 million to manufacture. The repeaters and submerged electronics cost over $12 million, and the installation cost $1.5 million. Together with a half million dollars spent on terminal stations and land equipment, the system came to just over $22 million US dollars.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This cable was originally laid in 1905 by Germany and connected the Micronesian island of Yap with American-held Guam. In 1916 the Japanese military seized the cable and redirected the link from Yap to Okinawa, extending their communications network in the region.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: AT&T

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Transpacific Cable-2 established a shortcut across the ocean. While all previous cables across the Northern Pacific had stopped at Midway Island, and sometimes Wake Island, TPC-2 jumped straight from Hawai‘i to Guam, leapfrogging the nodes in between.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1897-?; Okinawa Maru; System 850.1 km. Single conductor with gutta percha insulation (see AtlanticCable.com)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: These islands, south of Japan, were linked by telegraph in 1912. Like many Japanese networks during this period, this system was part of an attempt to control territories that had been annexed less than a generation before.

At the turn of the twenty-first century, three cables came ashore on the rural coast of western Oregon. While systems of the coaxial period usually terminated close to shore, these lines wound inland for over seventy miles, through the fir-populated mountains of the Tillamook State Forest to a Portland suburb nestled in the heart of “Silicon Forest.” The area was granted this nickname in 1981, only a few years after Intel established a research campus there. Yet the seeds of Silicon Forest were planted much earlier. In the 1930s, the U.S. Forest Service Radio Lab was created in Portland, and built wireless technologies to track fires as they spread through the forest, including the one that now borders the cable route. Engineers at the Radio Lab eventually developed two of Portland’s most well-known technology companies, setting the stage for today’s high-tech boom. Hillsboro, Oregon is now home to computer researchers, chip manufacturers, and cable stations, and is a budding hub of data center activity. Companies are drawn to Silicon Forest because of its “welcoming” environment: not only do companies get massive tax breaks in Hillsboro’s E-Commerce zone, but they have immediate access to cheap hydroelectric power from the nearby Columbia River.

The Southern Cross Cable Network was designed as an Internet-based cable that, at the time, would be the fastest and most straightforward route from Australia and New Zealand to the United States. Just as Southern Cross was being put in the water, the cable market collapsed – this was brought on by a combination of the excess capacity offered by the numerous cable systems laid in the late 1990s. The timing of Southern Cross was “perfect,” as its builders recollect, poised on the crest of the cable boom: if they'd started a little bit later, it likely wouldn't have happened.

Tata Communications
China Telecom,  China Unicom,  Chunghwa Telecom,  KT,  Verizon Business,  NTT,  AT&T

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Bamfield was a critical gateway during the telegraph era, a site where international signals punctured Canada and threaded it to other territories around the world. Yet this station was considered one of the most remote places in the Pacific Cable Board’s network due to the difficulties of regional transport. The nearby inlet was known as the “graveyard of the Pacific” for its numerous wrecks; the coastal Telegraph Trail served as a lifeline for their survivors. One cableman recollects that even though it was only one hundred and twenty miles to Victoria, the largest city on Vancouver Island, “you might as well have been a thousand miles away for all the difficulties in transportation.” The town had no road access until 1963 and in order to visit, one has to drive hours along narrow gravel logging roads, avoiding trucks that barrel down without warning and stir up clouds of dust in their wake. In the small town, which consists of a motel, a bar, and a handful of stores, young people are strolling along the streets, divers are suiting up, and trucks are fitted out for recreational camping. Bamfield would not be a destination for so many visitors if it were not for the establishment of a marine science center, which transformed the abandoned cable station into labs and classrooms.

In the 1920s, the Pacific Cable Board lay a higher capacity system, a "loaded cable" that eventually transmitted 150 words/minute directly from Suva, Fiji to Auckland, bypassing Norfolk Island. Thus began the era in the South Pacific of skipping over intermediate islands to ensure more "direct" routing.

This rural station in Central California has been a cable hub since 1964, when a telephone cable to Hawai'i was routed through Morro Bay. Constructed by AT&T, its location was midway between San Francisco and Los Angeles placed it out of the way of potential nuclear attack. Although the state has been a hub in communication technology, it has also played an important role in the growth of the environmental movement and the preservation of wilderness areas. Daniel Press articulates the apparent contradiction: “at the vanguard of paradoxical trends, California is one of the fastest growing states in the country, but is the most ambivalent about change.” Today, Central California is a site of conflict between these two forces. Fishermen and environmentalists regularly pose challenges to infrastructure development.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: San Luis Obispo Do Not Dig
San Luis Obispo cable route sign

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The third link between Hawai'i and the United States was a straightforward engineering project. AT&T needed more transpacific capacity, and as in their previous systems, collaborated with Hawaiian Telecom to build the infrastructure that would meet their needs. As a result, the two companies would then own all of the circuits on the system, blocking out any other telecommunications companies from ownership.
Hawaii-5 was AT&T's second fiber-optic cable between California and Hawai'i, yet like their first fiber-optic link, the line was economically obsolete in only twelve years.

The Hawai'i-2 telephone cable was the second link between the United States mainland and Hawai'i. Extended in 1964, it connected to a transpacific link that shuttled signals onward to Japan. For the system, a new station was constructed on O'ahu's west shore, which would become a critical hub for internet signals half a century later.

Trans-Pacific Cable 5 was one of the first ring systems in the Pacific. It has two branches between Japan and the U.S.: a direct northern route and a southern crossing via Hawai'i and Guam, where it interconnects with other global networks. More than 70 telecom companies from over 40 countries were involved in its construction, and two-thirds of its capacity was reserved before it entered service in the mid-1990s. TPC-5’s southern line carried high-definition television broadcasts for the 1996 Summer Olympic Games in Atlanta.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: At the beginning of the twentieth century, Cottesloe turned to the ocean. The Perth-Freemantle Railway, opened just two decades before, had brought settlers and visitors to the coast. Beach-going was only a newly popular pastime, but by the early 1900s, thousands visited Cottesloe’s shores each weekend. Pine trees endemic to Norfolk Island, a Pacific island also populated by undersea cables, were planted to enhance the beach’s appeal. Around the same time, the Eastern Extension Cable Company extended a link across the Indian Ocean to Cottesloe. On the shore, they built a multi-story red brick building, where the signals came in as quickly as ocean waves. In 1937, the cable station manager boasted that “the only time throughout the entire year when there is a cessation of activity in these stations, is on Armistice Day, when the instruments are closed down for a period of two minutes.” Even though they were separated from the city of Perth, cablemen remained connected to urban life via the copper wire, at least until July 31, 1966, when the station finally closed. The cable itself remains, stretching across Cottesloe’s sandy beach, its insulation unfurling as it decays.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: “A Fifteen Minute Broadcast Given by Mr. H. A. Colliver of Cottesloe Branch,” The Zodiac (1937): 276.
Margaret Miller, Gentlemen of the Cable Service: A Pictorial History of Australia’s Overseas Cable Telecommunications Service, 1870-1934 (Sydney: OTC Australia and Publimedia, 1992), 10.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Built by the Eastern Extension, Australasia and China Telegraph Company between 1901 and 1902, this cable was part of a larger project to connect Australia and London via British colonies in the Indian Ocean and South Africa.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1926-1966; Telcon; Eastern Extension Australasia & China Telegraph Company

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This system, established in 1926, was one of a new breed of "continuously loaded" cables. These cables dramatically expanded the capacity of the telegraph network, in some places offering speeds of over 2000 letters per minute.

You land on a beach on the Central California coast. You're in between two of the first nodes for internet traffic, Stanford University and the University of California Santa Barbara, and two hundred miles from the major internet technology hub in Silicon Valley. This is where the Internet enters the United States via undersea cable. The landscape is anything but technological. Behind you, an expansive state park wraps around the California coast. It is cold and rainy. Fog covers the ocean, but it deters neither surfers nor the signals transiting invisibly beneath the beach. From here, signals extend outward to Hawai'i, Guam, Japan, and onward to much of Asia. In what direction will you go?

The Japan-U.S. cable network was one of several ring networks laid at the turn of the twenty-first century. It cost over a billion dollars and has connected three landing sites in Japan with two U.S. stations via a direct northern route and a southern route through Hawai'i. Owned by a 35-member consortium, the cable has been upgraded to transmit more than 15 times its original capacity.

Just south of San Francisco's famous Cliff House, on Ocean Beach, over forty thousand people witnessed the landing of the transpacific telegraph in December, 1902. Eleven-year old Lucille Gage, the daughter of California's governor, broke a bottle of champagne over the cable. San Francisco had been the hub of telegraph traffic on the United States' west coast since the mid-nineteenth century. The first Overland Telegraph, linking San Francisco and New York City, had been completed in 1861. Just over a decade later, this network extended south to Santa Barbara, Los Angeles, and San Diego. From the late nineteenth century onward, San Francisco was a stopping point for telegraph traffic to the west coast and across the Pacific, almost all of which funneled through the city. Today, even though the area is a global center of high-tech development, little of this history remains. Cable systems migrated northward after World War II, and since then, not a single transoceanic network has landed in San Francisco.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: Pacific Telegraph and Telephone Company building

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Bondi Beach is perhaps better known as a world famous surfing locale than as a hotspot for undersea cables. Since the early twentieth century, however, Bondi has been the landing point for numerous telegraph, telephone, and fiber-optic cable systems. Located close to the center of Sydney, Bondi offers proximity for cable companies that seek to move in close to downtown markets. The most difficult part for cable layers is getting from the coastal beaches where cables land to the cable station, located in the center of the city. Given the lack of duct space under the streets, it is difficult to pave new paths in major urban areas.

The Pacific Cable Board cable was laid in 1902. It had been imagined for decades before it could actually be laid. It was only once the British came to value strategic communications that Sanford Fleming, a Canadian, was able to push the project through.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Eastern Extension's cables between Australia and New Zealand were relocated to Bondi Beach and Titahi Bay, outside of Wellington, in 1917.
In 1932, the shore end of the cable was moved north from Wellington to Muriwai Beach, outside of Auckland. As New Zealand's commercial traffic moved northward, so did the cables.

Tasman-1 was the second telephone cable laid across the Tasman sea, establishing 640 new circuits between Australia and New Zealand. A state sponsored affair, it was a collaboration of the Australia Overseas Telecommunications Commission and the New Zealand Post Office, and was manufactured by the British company Standard Telephone and Cables Limited. It cost 14.3 million.
In 1917, the 1890 cable across the Tasman Sea was diverted to Titahi Bay In New Zealand and to Bondi Beach in Australia.

The expansive Commonwealth Pacific Cable, which stretched across the Pacific from Hawai'i to New Zealand and Australia, was officially opened in 1963. The cable's management committee launched a multimedia blitz to publicize the system, publishing photos of cable stations, distributing booklets about the cable’s design, publicly tracking the cable ships, and issuing special stamps to commemorate the cable.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Softbank Telecom,  NTT,  Telstra,  Verizon Business,  AT&T

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1962, the balance of undersea cable power was shifting from British companies to the Americans. The Keawa‘ula cable station had just been built on O‘ahu’s west shore to land the Commonwealth Pacific Cable (COMPAC). British and Canadian transoceanic lines no longer stopped at Fanning Island, but rather, on United States soil. As a result, the construction of their cable station accorded with U.S. military specifications: it was located underground in a nuclear fallout shelter with thick walls and a decontamination chamber. Arriving at this station today, you see an elegant set of steps up leading up to a front wall comprised of square glass blocks. One transmission engineer describes Keawa‘ula as a “palace.” Designed by a local Honolulu-based firm, the station's aboveground expansion was inspired by a visit from the CEO of Teleglobe Canada in the 1980s. With little space for gathering inside, the staff members at the time held their meeting in a small and cramped lunch room. Afterward, the CEO saw the station workers outside, joking around and hanging out in the trees. In part inspired by the cable community, Teleglobe built a new, staff-friendly environment. The re-designed station grounded the communication hub in the heart of the cable family, yet left intact its Cold War foundations.

As PacRim West’s twinned project, PacRim East continues a line between Australia and New Zealand out to Hawai’i. It was the first fiber-optic cable laid along this route and a major multi-national investment in Australian-US telecommerce.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: American Samoa Government,  Elandia

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You come ashore via a British cable, laid in 1902 to connect colonial holdings across the Pacific. This link not only brought colonial commands, but external business investment, especially in Fiji's growing agriculture industry. As the cable brought market rates, ships brought indentured Indian laborers to work the sugar plantations. The island's economic development made it a well-liked hub by transiting cable men, who wrote about the station's short working hours, annual balls held by local sports clubs, and picnic trips up the river. By the mid-twentieth century, Fiji had become a full-fledged communications hub for the South Pacific, the only island with an extensive wireless network and cable routes to the north and south. It was not only British men who operated these systems. Local opportunities were developed for training and labor, including a wireless telegraph school and a cable depot. Fijian and Indo-Fijians, as well as Gilbertese, Ellice Islanders, and Solomon Islanders, helped to run the South Pacific communications network. Fiji not only depended on foreign signal traffic, but major Western powers depended on local infrastructures and support.

In the 1920s, the Pacific Cable Board lay a higher capacity system directly from Suva, Fiji to Auckland, bypassing Norfolk Island. Thus began the era in the South Pacific of skipping over intermediate islands to ensure more "direct" routing.

To get to California’s oldest still-operational cable landing point, established in Point Arena in 1957, you would have to travel over a hundred miles north from San Francisco along narrow wooded roads. The cable station is positioned on a bluff overlooking the Pacific. Across the road from the station, families picnic at a campsite. Cows graze in a nearby pasture. Between the station and the beach, a sign restricts access to a “sensitive habitat area.” At first glance these environments, and the signs indicating environmental preservation, appear to secure both wildlife and cables, protecting infrastructure from perception and potential tampering. But such environments also pose a problem to those laying undersea cables. At this station, cable builders had to undergo extra permitting,  and ultimately delay, to ensure that they did not endanger the Point Arena mountain beaver.

Hawaii-1 was the first telephone cable that stretched across the Pacific, linking up California with O'ahu. After 32 years of service it was retired, and it has since been re-purposed for scientific research.

One of the first fiber cable systems laid in the Pacific, Hawaii-4 was also one of the shortest lived. It went out of service after a mere 15 years, not because it broke, but rather due to economic obsolescence.

You land in the highest tonnage port in Australia, a zone of transit and transition. Vessels crowd the water – shipping boats, cruise ships, tugboats – and navigate slowly around oil wharves hovering farther out at sea. A few hundred kilometers inland, miners harvest iron ore and send it to Port Hedland via one of the many railway lines terminating there. This is a place where resources, both natural and human, are transferred between networks. From 1991 to 2004, the immigration detention facility here held large numbers of asylum-seekers that entered Australia by boat, many Iraqi and Afghan. The JASURAUS fiber-optic cable, laid in 1997, was just one more system that connected Australia to the world, circuiting a high-speed flow of information in and out of the busy port. Yet the process of interconnection was far from easy. To protect it from the port's traffic, the cable company designed an elaborate trenching scheme that would bury the cable fifty kilometers out to sea along a long shallow shelf. After this drawn out and exasperating process, the companies returned to the previous landing, in Perth, for their next cable. More recently, however, plans were floated for another submarine system, this time one in line with the area's history of extraction, linking Port Hedland to liquified natural gas platforms in Australia's Browse Basin.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: “Mining revs up again in the Pilbara,” The Sydney Morning Herald, accessed June 19, 2013, http://www.smh.com.au/news/business/mining-revs-up-again-in-the-pilbara/2006/01/10/1136863238766.html.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The JASURAUS cable was an innovative route, planned to connect Port Hedland on Australia's northwest coast with Indonesia in 1997. Yet after the difficulties in laying the system, subsequent cables were directed south to Perth. As JASURAUS's capacity was overwhelmed by the demands of modern Internet usage in the years to follow, it became a mere backup system for Australian traffic.

Banyuwangi means "Fragrant Water" in Javanese. Landing on its shores in the late nineteenth century, you emerge from vibrant blue waves. A gateway between Asia and Australia, this Dutch colony is a key stopping point for British telegraph cables. In 1871 a link to Darwin was landed here, connecting Australia to the rest of the world through Java’s shores. While more a century in the future, surfers will travel from around the world to ride Banyuwangi’s waves, nineteenth-century cablemen complain that its waters were “uninviting” because of the “ever-present danger of crocodiles and sharks.” Here the cable intersects both turbulent waters and an ancient spiritual history. From the sixteenth to eighteenth century, the city was the capital of the Hindi Kingdom of Blambangan, which controlled the eastern tip of Java before it was taken over by the Dutch. To dig a trench for the telegraph cable to Singapore, native convicts were employed as laborers. But when they unearthed a Hindu Temple from 700 AD, the laborers refused to continue and women, who reportedly were unaffected by the native “superstitions,” had to be called in to complete the job.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Wikivoyage contributors, “Banyuwangi,” Wikivoyage, accessed June 3, 2013, http://en.wikivoyage.org/wiki/Banyuwangi.
Wikipedia contributors, “Banyuwangi (city),” Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia, accessed June 3, 2013, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banyuwangi_(city).

“1871 Java – Port Darwin Cable,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 3, 2013, http://www.atlantic-cable.com/Cables/1871Java-PortDarwin/.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This was the first submarine telegraph line to Australia, laid by the British Australian Telegraph Company in 1871. Here it connected to the Overland Telegraph, which stretched almost 2,000 miles south to Adelaide. Although the undersea cable reached Darwin before the terrestrial link, it was severed in the ocean only shortly thereafter. Finally, after the submarine cable was repaired, Australia was enfolded into the British colonial network.

From 1889 to 1914, this cable was a vital link between Australia and the rest of the British Empire, providing the communications network necessary for international investment in the region’s mineral wealth. The cable station in Broome, “a palatial iron-structure, raised on stone pillars… with a splendid billiard room attached,” survives as a heritage building today, marked with a commemorative plaque detailing its cable history.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1879-1950; Telcon; Eastern Extension Australasia China Telegraph Co; Seine - Edinburgh (see AtlanticCable.com)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The first submarine cable connecting to Australia ran through areas prone to underwater disturbance, and seafloor activity caused multiple breaks in its initial years. This second cable was technically identical to the first, but diverged from the former cable route near Java, reducing the frequency of interruptions.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1889-1914; Telcon; Eastern Extension, Australasia & China Telegraph Company; Seine; Most of the cable was recovered during 1914-15 (see AtlanticCable.com)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: A second cable along the Broome-Java route proved necessary when seismic activity interrupted service on the primary line in 1890.

In 1908 the Dutch-German cable ship Von Podbielski finally reached Makassar, a small settlement on the Island of Celebes, “nearly half of which is still almost unknown,” or at least it was to colonial powers. The presumed half empty island was joined with the wider communications network in the Dutch East Indies in large part due to the thriving coffee crops under cultivation in the region.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1879-?; Telcon; Eastern Extension Australasia & China Telegraph Company; Scotia; Edinburgh (see AtlanticCable.com)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Completed at the end of 1879, this British cable linked colonies in Java to the central hub of Singapore. Technical difficulties and faults in the cable raised the cost of the project so much that additional financing had to be sought from the Australian colonial governments.

In September 1901, the Dutch East Indies government constructed a cable between Banjarmasin and Java as part of a new Dutch-German agreement “for the purpose of establishing telegraphic communication with their Colonial possessions in Asia.”

In the 1950s, the first transpacific telephone cable was landed at Hanauma Bay, solidifying Hawai‘i as a hub of Pacific communications. The station was buried underground like many Cold War-era infrastructures, disguised as part of the hillside to prevent it from attack. The burying of the station was not its only impact on the environment: installers had to dynamite their way through a reef to ensure the cable had a safe path out to sea. More than fifty years later, this path has become a corridor of environmental tourism. The hole in the reef, now dubbed the “Telephone Cable Channel,” draws scuba divers and snorkelers through one of Hawai‘i’s foremost nature preserves. The cable, once used to traffic telephone calls, has been re-purposed by marine scientists to monitor the undersea environment, sensing aquatic lifeforms and seismic movements of the ocean floor.
The Hawai'i-2 cable was a short link that connected the HAW-1 cable that landed at Hanauma Bay to the transpacific link that came ashore at Makaha. Laid in 1964, it held only 128 telephone circuits.

“Imagine yourself in a black room, with most of the light and air cut off by screens, and blinds, a mirror lamp burning close to you, and a temperature of about 95 in the shade,” recounts one cable worker of his time in Darwin. Conditions were rough for the early operators at Australia’s first undersea telegraph station, which hooked the continent into the colonial network in 1871. In the summer the temperature was often over 100 degrees Fahrenheit, even despite the Hindu and Aboriginal servants employed to “waft away the heat.” The quarters of the telegraph men frequently flooded and stores ran out of rations. When the cable was first landed, the men’s quarters had not even been built, and for two years they lived in tents. During this time the terrestrial cable linking Darwin to Adelaide went out frequently, cut by Aborigines across the continent. Even despite the hardships, the cablemen were still a privileged lot in this colonial outpost. Their rooms, once built, were “lofty,” and their station was eventually furnished with amenities like a piano and billiard table. “Perhaps the the greatest luxury they can boast of,” one reported, “is plenty of water gratis, for which others have to pay ninepence per bucket.”

Los Angeles is the only truly urban cable landing on the United States’ west coast. Although it is difficult to string systems into densely populated areas, the more pressing reason for rural cable stations is a legacy of the Cold War. AT&T set up cable stations far from cities in the 1950s and 60s, away from potential targets of nuclear attack. As long as AT&T remained in control, cables stayed at remote stations. But in the 1990s, after the company was broken up, new players in the cable business set up new landings, including this one in the affluent seaside town of Hermosa Beach. From here, cables wind twenty miles inland to a “carrier hotel,” One Wilshire, where it links to hundreds of other networks. One Wilshire, like the cable landing, was also established as a competitor to AT&T. Set up by MCI and Sprint, it was located just three blocks down the road from AT&T’s major switching center. Today it is  one of the country’s most important telecommunications hubs. As Wired Magazine reported, if this building went down “most of California and parts of the rest of the world would not be able to connect to the internet.”

Launched in 2010, the Unity cable was the first in nearly ten years to link the U.S. and Japan under the Pacific. As such, it increased capacity along this route by nearly twenty percent. A six-company consortium that includes Google owns the cable, with the Pacnet portion branded as EAC Pacific .

North of the original telegraph termination point at Weltevreden lies Jakarta’s post-independence cable hub. The area’s swamplands were once the home to the Dutch Fort Zouteland (“saline land”), and during the Japanese occupation of Jakarta during World War II, Ancol was the site of mass executions and burials. In films of the 60s and 70s, Ancol was portrayed as a mysterious and ghostly place. After Indonesia gained independence, the country’s founding President envisioned the transformation of Jakarta into a great international city, and coastal Ancol as a space for recreation, a “showcase of the nation.” His dreams were not recognized for decades, and even then, they came at a price. Developers dredged the nearby coast, destroying a beach that had made it accessible to Indonesia’s underclass, and converted the marshland for recreation facilities. Today, the theme park Ancol Dreamland, Sea World of Indonesia, resort hotels, and beaches are all accessible only with a fee.

James Bamford, The Shadow Factory: The Ultra-Secret NSA from 9/11 to the Eavesdropping on America (New York: Doubleday, 2008).

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The last coaxial cable laid to Australia, AIS connects the country with Indonesia, Singapore, and the wider international phone networks routed through the Pacific Basin. Its inadequacies were already apparent at its inauguration in 1986, however. As one official’s speech notes, “More needs to be done. The International Information Age requires it of us.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: France Telecom,  BT,  KDDI,  SingTel,  Telecom Italia Sparkle,  Telekom Malaysia,  AT&T,  Belgacom,  Communications Authority of Thailand,  China Telecom,  Deutsche Telekom,  Etisalat,  Telecom Egypt,  CTM,  PT Indonesia Satellite Corp.,  Jabatan Telecom Brunei,  KT,  Portugal Telecom,  Maroc Telecom,  PLDT,  Saudi Telecom,  Sri Lanka Telecom,  Turk Telekom,  Tata Communications,  Chunghwa Telecom,  Verizon Business,  KPN,  Telekom Austria,  SingTel Optus,  Telstra,  Vietnam Telecom International,  Omantel,  PCCW,  Pakistan Telecommunications Company Ltd.,  Cytaglobal,  eircom,  LG Uplus,  Softbank Telecom,  Telkom South Africa,  Rostelecom,  TPSA,  SingTel Optus,  Telecom Argentina,  Telecom New Zealand,  Myanmar Post and Telecommunication

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: A trading post since the second century, the island of Singapore was a hub of exchange for Southeast Asia long before the British settled there in 1819. When the first underwater telegraph cable arrived forty years later, Singapore was a bustling port city, what one nineteenth-century cable survey called “that thriving halfway house between Europe and the East.” Although produced in a factory in London more than six thousand miles away, the Singapore-Muntok cable was insulated with the coagulated sap of trees native to the region. The Malays had used this substance, known as gutta-percha, for generations to make whips and other products. In the 1840s, a Scottish doctor stationed in Singapore took notice of the sap and brought it back to London. Gutta-percha made an ideal electrical insulator and became the material of choice in the cable industry.  By the time gutta-percha-encased wires populated Singapore's waters, demand had all but wiped out the local flora that made its transmissions possible.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:

Chester G. Hearn, Circuits in the Sea: The Men, the Ships, and the Atlantic Cable. Westport, CT: Praeger Publishers, 2004. 10-11.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Submarine cables are usually laid, initiated, and then forgotten. Inaugurated in 1870, the Penang-Singapore line was hailed for bringing the East “into intimate connection with the living world of Western intellect and science.” Three years later, however, it was back in the news for something much more spectacular: a large tooth from a mysterious deep-sea creature was found wedged into the faulty cable line.

Linking Jakarta with Singapore, the line successfully was laid in 1881, replacing a broken cable system from 1870. Close to volcanic formations, yet safely secured underwater, the cable made Batavia a key site in the news coverage of the Krakatoa eruption of 1883.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1882-?; Manufactured by Telcon; Laid by Eastern Extension Australasia & China Telegraph Company; Seine

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1882 another telegraph line was extended between Singapore, a hub for Asian traffic, and Batavia.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1879-?; Telcon; Eastern Extension Australasia & China Telegraph Company; Scotia; Edinburgh (see AtlanticCable.com)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Following intense lobbying by governor Sir William Robinson, the British linked Penang and the central hub of Singapore to Malacca in 1879, introducing the latter city to the telegraph network of the Straits Settlements for the first time. The project also served the interests of Robinson’s homeland, providing another link in the chain of communications from Australia to India.
In 1897, the Eastern Extension Australasia & China Telegraph Company laid a second link between Penang, Malacca, and Singapore, duplicating the cable route established eighteen years before.

Typhoons and loneliness were the greatest perils for the cablemen working on the Cocos Islands in the early and middle twentieth century. Like Midway Island, the Cocos were largely uninhabited before the establishment of a cable station in 1901. The station was built at the highest point on the island: two meters above the high water mark, but this didn't keep it from damage during cyclones in 1907, 1911, and 1933. These caused flooding, collapsed palm trees onto the cable station houses, and wreaked havoc for international communications. During quieter moments, cablemen played tennis, staged theatrical performances, and waited eagerly for the arrival of supply ships every three months to bring food, mail, and mild excitement. Today, tourists seek out the Cocos for their quietude and isolation, sparsely and silently scattering themselves across the white beaches and blue-green waters. Floating just above the ocean’s surface, with no hills or mountains, these low-lying islands will face flooding in the coming years as climate change brings ashore ever-more intense storms.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1908-?; Telcon; Eastern Extension, Australasia & China Telegraph Co; Patrol (see AtlanticCable.com)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This system, laid in 1908 between the Cocos Islands and Batavia, gave the Eastern Extension company a diverse route from the Cocos Islands eastward.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1901-1966; Telcon; Eastern Extension Australasia & China Telegraph Co; Anglia (see AtlanticCable.com)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This line, a diverse pathway to Australia, was strung across the Indian Ocean in 1901. As a strategic asset during times of conflict, the Cocos cable station attracted armed aggression from the Germans in WWI and the Japanese during WWII, both of whom sought to fracture communications between colonial territories.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1922-?; Telcon; Eastern Extension Australasia & China Telegraph Co; Patrol (see AtlanticCable.com)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This 1922 cable reinforced an earlier link between the Cocos Islands and Batavia.

Madang is fairly small as far as cities go – about 30,000 people live here – but it is the capital and most populous part of its province. The city’s infrastructure is focused outward rather than inward. It is home to many of Papua New Guinea’s export industries, and the landing point for an international fiber-optic cable. The main occupation for many here is a large timber industry, which logs the nearby Gogol forest. In addition, the city exports copra, coffee, cocoa, and tobacco, and is home to tuna processing plants and engineering and joinery workshops. The people are also a mix – tourists, missionaries, and contract workers from countries around the world mingle with indigenous people speaking hundreds of different local languages. Papua New Guinea is considered one of the most culturally diverse places in the world, with over 300 different tribal groups living mainly in traditional societies. Only a small percentage live in urban, modernized centers like Madang and Port Moresby. But even cities within the country have trouble interacting with each other: the volcanoes that run through the middle of the island have prevented any roads from being built between them.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Haiveta Kivia, “Telikom optic-fibre improves business,” Post-Courier Online, July 24, 2012, accessed July 10, 2013, http://www.postcourier.com.pg/20120724/business01.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The South-East Asia Communications system, a coaxial network laid in the mid 1960s, terminated in Cairns, Australia. Here it was linked via a microwave link to Sydney. But as one engineer recalls, this last wireless segment “was nothing but trouble. The cable would often just continually fail. Not because of the cable system, but the backhaul link between Cairns and Sydney.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Pipe Networks

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: “The outside world, with its quips and cranks, is shut out, and we are a community unto ourselves,” one cableman writes of New Zealand’s first undersea telegraph station, established in 1876. Arriving on Cable Bay's shore, you find it relatively isolated from even the nearest town. With few women present, the cablemen of the Wakapuaka station have formed their own tight-knit family, with bonds built from male comradeship. They spend their off-hours fishing in the bay, playing tennis at the station’s courts, producing a Saturday night theatrical show, and drinking heavily. The most memorable events are recorded in their amateur “newspaper,” the Cable Bay Recorder, which takes a sometimes satirical spin on station life. By the early 1890s, Cable Bay has become a recruitment point and training station for the telegraph company, at times bringing new men in through family contacts. Although station life is flourishing and the staff has increased from only 7 to 17, in the years that come competition from the Pacific Cable Board in the north and a disastrous fire will ultimately force the company to move the landing to Wellington. Almost a century later, all that will be left of the vibrant cable family is "Cable Bay Holiday Park," a campground where images of station life hang on the recreation room's walls.

In 1876 the Eastern Telegraph Company laid a trans-Tasman cable from Botany Bay to Nelson, where they sought to interconnect with economic trade then centralized in New Zealand’s South Island. A recollection of this link, the first to New Zealand, proclaims: “Cut off by 13,000 miles of sea, and six months in time, from their homeland, British colonists living in remote New Zealand in 1876 suddenly found themselves linked with England—of nostalgic memory—by submarine cable. Thirty-six years of isolation was at an end.”

A second cable was laid by Eastern Extension between La Perouse, Australia and Nelson, New Zealand in 1890, where it would function until 1917, when it was relocated to nearby urban centers in Sydney and Wellington.

Landing on Midway, you glide up a soft white beach to green grasses. Before 1903, the island was completely desolate, with little vegetation or life. When the Commercial Pacific Cable Company established the Midway cable station, the high winds and blinding glare of the white sand meant that cablemen had to wear goggles when they went outside. Shiploads of soil were brought in from Hawai‘i so that the men could plant grass. The cable company also imported chickens, cows, trees, and other plants to make the area shady and sustainable. One cablemen recounted that they had found the island “bare and have made it beautiful.” Life on Midway was quiet and often lonely for the twenty-four men stationed there, over 1300 miles away from the nearest inhabited island, but they took pride in their tropical home, broadcasting its happenings in the cable network’s magazine. After the Second World War, and the infamous battle that occurred here, Midway continued to be an important node in cable networks, first as a stopping point for a transpacific telephone cable and later as a cable listening post for the U.S. Navy's Sound Surveillance System.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: “The Transformation of Midway Island,” The Zodiac: The Journal of the Submarine Cable Service XI, no. 129 (April 1919): 230.
“The Gooney Clarion,” The Zodiac 6, no. 61-72 (June 1912- May 1913).

“Midway Island,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 7, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/CableCos/Midway/.
Wikipedia contributors, “Midway Atoll,” Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia, accessed June 7, 2013, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midway_Atoll.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: On the northwestern edge of Australia, Cairns gazes out across a serene blue-green sea. These peaceful waters are deceptive – underneath the surface there are mud flats, and farther out to sea, the Great Barrier Reef. The muddy, shallow bottom of the ocean means that Cairns is not the beach town it would seem destined to be. It caters primarily to tourists who stop by on their way to the reef, the area’s main attraction, which draws in flows of visitors every year, many of whom rely on the area's communications networks. In 1967, Cairns received its first cable: a link to Papua New Guinea, extending onward to Guam and Hong Kong. Nine years later, a second link was set up between Cairns and Papua New Guinea. The city remained a sort of branch outpost for Australia, a landing point for cables on the country's northern coast, until APNG was withdrawn from service in 1996. While its location at the tip of Australia makes it a natural outlet to Asia, the inland cable that connected these networks to Sydney has often caused problems, and the Great Barrier Reef, challenging to lay cables across, makes it difficult to bring signals in and out from abroad.

The Australia-Papua New Guinea cable was laid between Port Moresby and Cairns in 1975, becoming operational in 1976. The cable, like many others of this generation, outlasted its design life, serving Papua New Guinea until it was replaced by APNG-2 in 2006.

In Australia, you come ashore where Captain Cook first staked the British Flag in 1770 and where French explorer La Perouse later landed in 1788. Winds whip around the headlands, agitating waves even in the sheltered bay. Although you are ten kilometers south of Sydney, this location was selected as a cable landing in part due to its nautical history, which in turn later attracted military installations. Even after the telegraph station was closed for signal traffic, the building continued to serve the surrounding area. It was used briefly as quarters for Coast Hospital nurses and subsequently as a women’s refuge operated by the Salvation Army. Communications, however, were redirected to central Sydney. The builders of at least one subsequent cable system still toyed with the idea of returning to La Perouse, but decided it was too difficult to move the line. In contrast, nautical traffic accelerated. Just down the shore, Port Botany is one of the nation's largest container ports, funneling consumer products through the bay to the rest of the country. The old telegraph station (now a museum), a nearby watchtower (originally meant to look out for smugglers), and a monument named for the early French explorer are reminders that contemporary transit is rooted in historical currents.

According to Maori legend, New Zealand's North Island is a giant fish dragged up from the sea. Wellington, in the south, is the fish's head, and Northland, where Doubtless Bay lies, is the tail. The bay's name, however, comes from more recent sailors. When Captain James Cook sailed by the inlet in 1769, the weather made it difficult to enter and he recorded it "doubtless a bay." In 1902, in part because of its northern location, the first transpacific cable was landed here. The cable layers initially considered the Parengarenga Harbour, closer to the island's North Cape, but the location was too far from populated areas. Ahipara, on the west coast, was also considered, but this too was far from any existing telegraph lines. Although Doubtless Bay - far enough north, yet still possessing infrastructure - was established as a final middle ground, it was eventually replaced by Auckland as the entry point for New Zealand's northward-bound signal traffic. The remnants of the cable, rendered inoperational over a century ago, continue to surface periodically on the beach and pieces have been cut out of it for the regional museum. Parts of the cable complex also remain: they have been carted inland to house the area's cinema theater.

Sanford Fleming and the Canadian Government mobilized arguments about security to establish the first transpacific cable system in 1902, creating a foundational route for all north-south Pacific traffic. This system mastered the scale of the globe: the Pacific Cable Board line between Bamfield, Canada and Fanning Island was then the longest undersea cable in the world. This system also required new expenditures for infrastructure and planning. A new 8,000 ton ship, the Colonia, had to be constructed specifically for the line.

Founded in 1860 as a Russian naval post, the city of Vladivostok, “Ruler of the East," is fraught with contradictions. In the late 1800s, the military presence permeated the city, but the orderliness it instituted was offset by sailors’ gambling and drunkenness. At the same time, Vladivostok was a cosmopolitan center filled with a “polyglot crowd.” Businessmen from around the world were drawn by the city’s natural harbor and investor privileges. The Danish Great Northern Telegraph Company used Vladivostok as a connection point for their trans-Siberian cable and undersea links to Nagasaki and Shanghai – an important alternative to the British-dominated global network. The cable boosted the city’s international business as well as the dissemination of naval intelligence, and the telegraph company was granted a forty-year lease on a prime piece of land. Several cablemen were employed in a stately three-story office building to handle the traffic. In the 1930s, under Joseph Stalin’s repressive regime, Vladivostok changed profoundly. Many of its ethnic inhabitants were forcibly removed, and the city became a distribution point for Stalin’s political prisoners. Fearing espionage, the government removed foreigners from the Great Northern telegraph stations, and the cable line was left in Russian hands. In the following years, as Vladivostok changed from “colony of non-Russian powers” to a “city of workers,” multi-story apartment buildings were constructed where the telegraph office once stood, with statues of a worker, a farmer, a sailor, and a guard adorning the rooftop. Today the building has returned to its international roots: it is home to the Barbados Hostel.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1883, the Great Northern Telegraph Company's line between Vladivostok, Nagasaki, and Shanghai was duplicated.

For roughly two decades beginning in the late 1970s, this small village in the northwest Philippines was linked to the urban centers of Singapore, Hong Kong, and Okinawa. By 1980, Currimao was considered one of the largest and most advanced cable hubs in the region, well-staffed by cablemen who maintained its terminal equipment, power plant, and cable lines. But when the Asia-America Gateway system was being built in the early 2000s, the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company selected a landing site more than a hundred miles south in the province of La Union, closer to Metro Manila. As quickly as it appeared, Currimao faded from the network map and the former station was transformed into a museum. Today the town is perhaps best known for a series of coral rock formations, shaped by the ocean into dramatic caverns and spires over thousands of years.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Completed in 1980, the TAILU coaxial cable connected Taipei and Luzon, hooking the Philippines into the undersea cable network and transforming the country’s prior practice of routing telephone calls via microwave radio.

You are carried to Baler’s shores with nine-foot waves surging overhead, curling in on themselves and frothing as they meet the warm, sandy beach. This coastal town was once entirely decimated by the “tromba marina,” a tsunami wave that inundated the area in 1735. The surf still looms large in people’s minds. Locals claim that at times they hear it as far away as the provincial capitol building, almost a mile inland. Even beyond the city, Baler’s surf is more famous than its land. Between October and March, when the waves are the largest, the ocean teems with bodies and boards. Like the town’s sole undersea cable, surfing came to Baler because of global media flows. A little over a decade after the transpacific telephone cable arrived, a scene from the film Apocalypse Now was shot on Baler’s beaches. In it, a surf-crazed colonel pushes his troops to ride the waves amidst enemy gunfire. A recreated Vietnamese village was blown up and the trees along the shore were burned. After filming, the crew left behind their surfboards and a new sport.

Only 108 square kilometers, Rodrigues Island was formed by volcanic eruptions 1.5 million years ago, making it both very small, and geologically, very young. For most of its short history, Rodrigues remained sheltered from extensive human intervention or cultivation. In the 17th and 18th centuries the Dutch and the French tried to settle and farm here, but their efforts were stymied by loneliness more so than the land itself. The French, who had brought African slaves from Mauritius, eventually gave up on farming and exhausted the island’s large tortoise population, using it to supply meat to passing ships. When the British took possession of Rodrigues in 1809, slavery was abolished and the freed slaves and colonists built a small but somewhat stable economy through tobacco and food exports. With commerce came communication, and in 1901 the British landed a telegraph cable here, stopping between Mauritius and the Cocos Islands.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Fanning Island was linked via the Pacific Cable Board’s telegraph cable in 1902, becoming an integral part of the British Empire’s communications network. Ernest Shackelton, famed Antarctic explorer, once wrote a poem about the island: “Surf-bound, lonely islet, Set in a summer sea, Work of a tiny insect, A lesson I learn from Thee— For to your foam-white shores, The deep sea cables come; Through slippery ooze, by feathery palm, Flies by the busy hum, Of Nations linked together, The young with the older lands, A moment’s space, and the Northern tale Is placed in Southern hands.” Despite the Empire’s dependence on Fanning, it was the most geographically remote station on the line, and cablemen dreaded moving there. Many men were separated from their families for over two years, and the station’s sports and camaraderie were little substitute for the comforts of home. In part because of the island’s poor infrastructure, when coaxial cable replaced the telegraph in the 1960s, Fanning was bypassed, the cablemen left, and an era ended for the island’s Gilbertese inhabitants.

This northern suburb of Auckland, New Zealand, has been an outlet for northward communications for more than a century. In 1912, after a new Chief Post Office was opened in central Auckland, the Pacific Cable Board re-directed their cable from rural Doubtless Bay to Takapuna Beach. The workers from the station came with the cable, and the cable station was set up on in the Post Office, consolidating networks formerly distributed across the land. As the cable continued to function without major disruptions, networks in the following decades continued to follow the same path. When the Southern Cross Internet cable was set up in 2000, it too landed on the Takapuna shore. In the cable industry, the prevailing logic is to go with the tried and true.

Sanford Fleming and the Canadian Government mobilized arguments about security to establish the first transpacific cable system in 1902, creating a foundational route for all north-south Pacific traffic. This system mastered the scale of the globe: the Pacific Cable Board line between Bamfield, Canada and Fanning Island was then the longest undersea cable in the world. This system also required new expenditures for infrastructure and planning. A new 8,000 ton ship, the Colonia, had to be constructed specifically for the line.

Moving across this cable landing, you are careful not to sink into the ditches that dot the landscape. Trash clutters the beach, and nearby, shots are fired at the end of Rifle Range Road. The station at Vatuwaqa, like so many others, was built in a largely industrial, suburban area just north of Fiji's capital city, Suva. Yet unlike many contemporary cable stations, it is a place where people as well as signals come together. Men who work for Fiji's international telecommunications company are hanging out around the building. A dog lazily watches the front gate. Inside is a room constructed specifically for teleconferencing, where the company imagined new kinds of business relationships would emerge. As you pass through, you find a sense of camaraderie and hospitality among the cable workers. This is a place for meeting, for connecting, and for understanding cable history. In the courtyard, a monument commemorates the site's development as a satellite earth station, the landing point of the ANZCAN cable, and later, the Southern Cross system.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: When the Spanish took possession of Manila in the sixteenth century, they brought galleon trade ships, Christian missionaries, and tobacco seeds. They also brought the "polo y servicio," a practice of forced labor in which indigenous Filipinos were put to work on colonial infrastructure and agriculture. By the late 19th century, Manila’s streets were host to both a growing commercial sector and a deep-seated resentment that eventually erupted into guerilla resistance. In 1880, a cable was laid to Hong Kong to Bolinao, extending arduously overland to the capital city. By the time the Manila cable station finally opened for service in 1887, the Philippine Revolution was in full swing. The link was repeatedly cut by revolutionary forces and within a year it was replaced by a submarine cable to Manila Bay. Yet even that cable was not safe from strife – the Spanish-American War started in 1898, bringing about further conflict and cable disruption. When the United States finally replaced Spain as the colonial force in the region, they turned to secure their new territory from the indigenous resistance, leaving up to one million Filipino casualties. Eager to solidify their power in the Philippines, the Americans laid another cable, connecting Manila to the United States via Guam and Honolulu. In the years that followed, they used telegraph networks to surveil Filipino leaders and safeguard their empire.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: To many early visitors, Kawaihae appeared a barren and desolate place. Its arid landscape on the leeward side of Hawai’i’s big island supported little agriculture. Despite this, in the late 1700s it was the residence of King Kamehameha and a staging ground for the conquest of the Hawaiian archipelago. Though the translation of Kawaihae is “Water-of-Wrath,” like Kamehameha, many of the area’s early residents used the water to their advantage, trading both fish and salt extracted from the ocean. Kawaihae’s sheltered bay also brought European merchants ashore, transforming the community into a “depot of goods for the interior.” Cattle were imported and native Hawaiians were forced to harvest sandalwood from the island’s interior forests. The exchange of goods made local resources even more scarce. The cattle ran wild, endangering residents and destroying Kawaihae’s cultivated land. The sandalwood trade brought about massive deforestation. Although Kawaihae’s port receded in importance in the late 1800s, trade has since been revived. In 1970, the United States Army Corps of Engineers excavated the harbor with nuclear explosives, making way for imports and exports once again. Undersea cables land not far from the port, connecting the area to New Zealand, Tahiti, California, and the rest of the archipelago.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 2010, the Honotua cable – stretching between Hawai‘i and Tahiti – was made possible by funding from the French Government, granted as part of a wider measure to extend broadband to French citizens and improve the country’s digital economy.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You surface on the shore of a tiny island off the northeastern coast of Malaysia. Nestled safely within the Brunei Bay, the spot is ideal for the traffic of signals, ships, and resources: the British once thought Labuan would become a "second Singapore." Initially occupied in order to combat piracy in the region, the island soon became the site of important British coal fields. British ships also stopped here as they traversed the South China Sea – the harvesting of coal made it both an export center and a fueling point for the Imperial Navy. The territory became a stopping-point for another network at the end of the nineteenth century: a cable was laid to connect Singapore and Hong Kong by way of Labuan. This flat, green island remained relatively unsettled by the British, who used it almost exclusively for its ore and harbor. Today, Labuan’s development continues to depend on its ocean-going history. Scuba divers come here to explore old sunken ships, oil and gas companies drill for modern energy sources, and corporations from around the world reap the benefits of the island's offshore financial center.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Matrix Cable System lands on the unlikely shores of Pantai Mutiara, an artificial peninsula that hosts some of Jakarta’s most extravagant luxury housing and amenities. Inspired by Australia’s Gold Coast, each of the homes in the Pantai Mutiara complex offers its own private boat dock with a canal to the ocean. As a gated satellite town, it also provides residents local access to hospitals, mega-malls, two golf courses, and the international airport. Not unintentionally, this serves to minimize their interactions with the rest of the city, especially the many “kampongs,” or indigenous neighborhoods. In order to secure waterfront property, Matrix Cable System had to buy and convert a beach-area condo to house their cable station, which then helped them to blend in with their surroundings. Despite the expensive real estate, the insular nature of the neighborhood and its jutting projection far into the reclaimed sea make it an ideal pathway for a cable landing.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Haiphong was founded in the year 43 B.C.E. by Lê Chân, a female general of a Vietnamese revolutionary army. In response to increasing Chinese expansion and mistreatment, two sisters from a military family in a rural Vietnamese village overthrew their Chinese overlords, and formed this small, mostly-female army. From here, the Trưng Sisters’ forces expanded southwards and they liberated Vietnam within a matter of months. The Trung rule only lasted three years, after which the Vietnamese would again struggle against Chinese domination until French colonialism overpowered both Chinese and indigenous movements. Haiphong, a name which means “defensive coastal area,” remained a strategic site through these many conflicts. The area’s deep harbor and location at the mouth of Cấm River made it an ideal center for French naval operations. When the French colonies were interconnected by telegraph cables, Haiphong was established as a stopping point for signals between Saigon and Amoy. In Vietnam today, the leaders of the ancient revolutionary uprising remain national heroes, and an imposing statue of Lê Chân stands watch over Haiphong’s waterways.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Long before it was a cable hub, Katong was a center of private wealth in British Malaya. Colonial elites established giant mansions, coconut plantations, and weekend villas along the waterfront in this East Singapore district from the early nineteenth century onwards. Though some of these structures have been preserved and restored, often painted bright colors, the still-affluent neighborhood has also seen some major physical transformations. The beach where you emerge from the APCN-2 network didn’t even exist before the 1970s. It was created as part of a massive land-reclamation project designed to add more space for housing on the island. Modern apartment towers and Singapore’s largest park now occupy the expanded coastal area. Soon after the artificial beach was completed, a telephone cable arrived from Hong Kong, followed by connections to regional fiber-optic networks in the 1990s and early 2000s.
