http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: There are only a few ways to get ashore at Norfolk Island. Rough seas batter the island’s high, rocky walls. There are no harbors or ports. Strong currents make entry difficult at the one feasible cable landing site, Anson Bay, and even here landslides can take out the hillside. Despite these difficulties, the island was determined to be the only feasible geographic location to land the first transpacific cable after it snaked down from Fiji and before it branched off to Australia and New Zealand. Norfolk’s inaccessibility had once made it an ideal location for a convict settlement, yet this had been closed almost fifty years prior to the cable’s arrival. Migrants from Pitcairn, the descendants of the Bounty mutineers, have taken up residence in the penal buildings. The island’s insularity coupled with a lack of cable traffic produced a set of unique connections here. For a period of time, the cableman on night duty in Southport would send newspaper extracts to Norfolk Island, where they were typed up by the operator and “tacked up on a tree at the crossroads for all to read.” This news source was known as the “Tree of Knowledge.” By the 1920s, with the development of automatic relays, far fewer staff were needed on Norfolk Island and the cable community diminished.

On New Zealand’s rural west coast, a coaxial cable extends out from a sand bank, over a small pond of water, and back into the beach before it heads to Sydney. Aquatic creatures have incorporated its eroding armor and still strong copper core into their home. Old cables dating to the telegraph era have surfaced on this beach: the first international link landed over a century ago, in 1912. Cost-cutting during the Depression prompted the cable company to re-locate a second link, formerly in Wellington, here in 1932. From Muriwai cables extend inland over twenty miles to the growing city of Auckland. This terrestrial path is almost as fraught as the surf-beaten shores of Muriwai. In 1952, incorrectly gauging the location of the cable system, a road grader severed the international network for five hours. After this, the cable companies ensured that the network was marked extensively for the local community.

You arrive at the “Amsterdam of the tropics,” or so the Dutch East India Company imagined it when they built up Jakarta to support the spice trade. Streets and canals are named after Dutch provinces and cities, and the city is named Batavia, after Dutch tribal ancestors. The oldest part of the town, built near the coast and surrounded by walls, is the hub of a far-flung trade network. To the south, Weltevreden is ordered, regulated, and home to shops and government offices. Through and through, the colonial landscape is structured to facilitate the smooth flows of trade. Yet it is also designed to separate colonists from the Javanese. When the first undersea cable was landed in 1859, the telegraph station molded to the city’s organization. The “cable colony” is now “one of the favourite stations in the Extension Co.” – it has a rambling garden, tennis courts, stables, a reading room, and a broad entryway flanked by palm trees. As is true in the rest of Jakarta, the station’s non-European laborers are excluded from the extravagant lifestyle of the cablemen, relegated instead to neighborhoods “in and around the European city.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, "Cable Timeline: 1845-1900," History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 29, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
“Batavia: The Exiles' Mess,” The Zodiac, 1922. Held in the Cable & Wireless Archives.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Dutch 19th century telecommunications interests, motivated by a growing antipathy to the English, soon found an ally in France. The expansion of the East Indies network continued in 1905 with partial French financing of a connection between Batavia, Billiton, and Pontianak.

As a key British treaty port in the wake of the first Opium War, Shanghai rapidly developed as a contact zone for international powers. The city brought together a mix of cultures, architectural styles, and social classes, but these connections were made possible by the exploitation of Chinese labor and a concession system that granted foreigners immunity to Chinese law. The first telegraph cable arrived in 1871, covertly brought ashore in the middle of the night by the Great Northern Telegraph Company. In the ensuing years more cables were laid without official Chinese sanction. Without the cooperation of the Chinese people, however, cables remained vulnerable to disruption. Enterprising pirates stripped cables for resale. Local villagers ripped down lines that disturbed ancestral grave sites and the landscape’s feng shui. Men armed with rifles had to patrol the Yangtze River to stop sailors from throwing anchor and severing the cable. The situation was ameliorated by degrees when, in 1875, the Chinese government offered official recognition and protection to the cables in exchange for ownership of the illegal lines upstream of Shanghai. A period of relative stability followed, as China slowly developed an overland monopoly on telegraph lines while colonial powers built ever more underwater connections.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This German-laid telegraph cable, installed in 1900 amid the Boxer Revolution, provided vital communications between Imperial and colonial powers that were working to quash the uprising. Decades later, after World War I, it was taken over by the British.
In 1900 the German post and telegraph service laid their own system between Tsingtau and Shanghai.
in 1914, the Japanese Military extended a link to Shanghai from Nagasaki.
This cable, originally laid by the German-Netherlands Telegraph company, was diverted to Okinawa by the Japanese in 1916.

Ninomiya was the first landing site for trans-Pacific coaxial cables in Japan, built in 1964 to receive TPC-1 from Guam. As one of the oldest still-operational stations in the country, it served as a training ground for Japanese cable workers, some of whom later became leaders in the industry. For a period of time, it was also a hotbed of submarine cable research, where new cable technologies were designed and developed. Unlike many modern stations, however, it is located in a central residential area populated by commuters to Odawara and Tokyo-Yokohama. Even though Ninomiya is linked to these urban areas, the greenery of Azumayama Park makes them easy to leave behind. Climb up the hill behind the station and you will enter the park, passing several shrines and temples on your journey to the summit. Dense woods open onto a grassy plain with commanding views of Sagami Bay and Mount Fuji. Artist Hokusai Katsushika included this vista in his series of woodblock prints of Fuji as seen from different Japanese towns, drawing Ninomiya into an early-nineteenth-century visual network.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Reliance Globalcom

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The British colony of Adelaide entered the underwater network in 1872. Telegraph signals traveled through overland lines to Port Darwin and, from there, to London via Singapore and India. Previously, messages between Europe and Australia were carried by ship and took upwards of eighty days to reach their destinations. Now they could be sent in a matter of hours. In 1901, Adelaide received its first submarine connection to the old world by way of Perth and Durban, South Africa. “Whilst buoying” the cable offshore near Kangaroo Island, notes an Eastern Extension Company cable ship officer, it “got foul of the propellers on account of the strong current; it took us six hours to get it clear, but no damage was done.” Once untangled, the line joined Adelaide’s General Post and Telegraph Office, a grand stone and brick building adorned with a clock tower. Built in the early 1870s to receive the first international telegraph signals, the station was soon expanded to include a telephone exchange.

Unlike most cable hubs, Palembang is not on a coast, but instead about 40 miles inland from the South China Sea, in the southeast corner of Sumatra. Because of its location on the Musi River, the city has long been a trading and maritime center. The wide, grey river runs directly through the town, dividing the city into halves, and, during the colonial period, easing the arrival of large military and merchant ships. On one bank, a walled city was built by the Dutch, while the opposite bank remained lined with smaller traditional wooden houses on stilts with deep red roofs. The Musi River both divided and connected – the Dutch East Indies Company to open a trading post here in 1619, and by the 18th century, over 50,000 pounds of spices were exported from the city every year. The telegraph cable, brought in 1859, was used in part to transmit information about this trade. The last section of cable had to be laid using proas, local vessels which snaked 60 miles of cable up the narrow and deep river to its widening at the shores of Palembang.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1903, the Eastern Extension Australasia and China Telegraph Company was invited by the Dutch East Indies government “to connect Java, Borneo, and Sumatra with the islands of Billiton and Banka [Belitung and Bangka],” notes an issue of The Electrician from that year. “When these cables are established it is expected that they will not only prove a great convenience to the Government and mercantile community, but act as important feeders to the Company’s system” of submarine lines.

A mere twelve feet above sea level, this string of three islands is the only evidence of a massive volcano that lies beneath. Wake, Pearle, and Wilkes Island wrap around a shallow, vibrant blue lagoon, the volcano's empty crater. Dangers are hidden on the atoll's shores, in the military installations from which the United States coordinates another kind of aerial explosion: military missile testing. Were it not for undersea cables, this island might never have become a United States possession. It was discovered in 1568 by Spanish explorers, but was dubbed a “low barren island.” In 1899, the US government annexed Wake Island with the hope of landing a cable there, but given the lack of fresh water and its inhospitable conditions, a station was never built. It was not until after the historic battle on Wake Island during World War II that it finally became a cable node. In 1964, the United States and Japan cooperated to land the first transpacific telephone cable here. Although all subsequent systems skipped over the island, Wake continues to serve a strategic function. Hydroacoustic arrays extend out to the seafloor, monitoring for underwater nuclear activity in the Western Pacific.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Tourists step on a long cable conduit without looking twice, intent on getting to the ruins of a World War II Japanese antiaircraft gun at the far end of Gun Beach. Few realize that Guam's strategic military value during the war was in part due to its undersea cable networks. Even fewer realize that the island remains one of the most connected places in the Pacific, with cables stretching out from its shores to the mainland United States, Asia, and Australia. At the other end of the beach is the Hotel Nikko, one of the early Japanese five-star hotels in the area, a building dependent on the island’s advanced communications infrastructure. At Tumon Bay, undersea cables bisect a material remnant of the Japanese wartime attack and one of the largest indications of Japanese development on the island, two sites with which cable communications are intertwined. The cable conduits themselves are worn down and blend in with the rocks on the beach. In the water their surfaces are smooth, but rippled, like the ocean. In them, one can see traces of the atmospheric and geological currents that have long positioned Guam at the center of transpacific movements.

Combined with the Tasman 2 and PacRim East cables, PacRim West provided a link between Australia, New Zealand, and existing transpacific networks. To do so, it even had to traverse the Mariana Trench near the coast of Guam. Completed in 1995, its data capacities were designed for an early age of Internet use, but proved inadequate just a few years later. The cable was decommissioned in 2005 and recycled to become part of the APNG-2 network.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: AT&T
Softbank Telecom,  NTT,  Telstra,  Verizon Business,  AT&T

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Was located at 44 Northam Road, now Jalan Sultan Ahmad Shah.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In George Town at the turn of the 19th century you witness the beginnings of a modern city. The streets are lined with warehouses and ghauts, wide steps leading from the street to the water. Banks, trading areas, and emporium stores are beginning to appear along Beach Street. Since its founding by the British East India Company in 1786, the town has grown into a bustling trading port and commercial center. George Town has been built on water: its commercial center stands on a swampy wetland that was leveled and filled in the early 1800s. English settlers built their bungalows high up on top of Penang Hill, forbidding natives to do the same. The settlers’ wealthy Chinese business partners were allowed to build in the middle part of the hill. The cable – part of the emerging modern city – surfaces close to the water, but ultimately connected those who lived far above it.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 22, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
Visions of Penang Archives Online (My Heritage My Penang), accessed June 22, 2013, http://www.visionsofpenang.com.my

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1891, the British Eastern Extension, Australasia & China Telegraph Company extended their network to Medan. The CS Recorder, a cable ship constructed only six years before, was tasked to lay the line. After it was completed, the ship repaired and maintained cables in the region for years.

A link between Penang and Rangoon was manufactured by Telcon and laid by the Eastern Extension Australasia & China Telegraph Company in 1877. The cable, 583 miles long, contained over 100 pounds of copper.
This system, the first link from India to Asia, was extended by the British Indian Extension Telegraph Company in 1870.

“On December 15,” declares a U.S. trade report, “the Eastern Telegraph Co.’s new cable from Penang to Colombo was established and its new cable system thrown open to traffic with London and with the Far East.” This 1913 cable was part of a much longer 12,000-mile connection between Lands End, England and Hong Kong (via Suez, Aden, Colombo, Penang, and Singapore). By avoiding slower overland lines and stopping points where a message has to be deciphered and retransmitted, the submarine cable greatly increased the speed and reliability of communication between Britain and its settlements in Asia.

When the cable ship Colonia reached Colombo Harbor on February 28th 1923, it made regional news. The expatriate paper The Times of India enthused that “it is impossible to estimate the improvements that will accrue from the new cable,” even though it merely replaced an identical line damaged in the First World War. With peace finally secured, infrastructural repairs were often a powerful symbol of modernization in the changing Pacific colonies.

The Tanguisson Beach station, built to house American networks during the Cold War era, resembles an underground bunker. Entering, you descend several stories down a fortified stairwell and even then, can only access the equipment room once admitted through a secure metal door. Immediately inside the entrance is a decontamination chamber, a former precaution for nuclear attack, and now a storage closet. Everything inside is redundant in case the domestic infrastructure fails. Multiple, completely separated generators comprise backups for building power and air-conditioning units. Independent battery plants sustain the equipment. During the coaxial era, Tanguisson was staffed by at least two employees at all times, but was often occupied by many more. On the wall, you witness evidence of the community formed here: yearbook-style photos of all of the AT&T stations in the Pacific, including Makaha, Keawa‘ula, Bandon, San Luis Obispo, and Point Arena. Each has an image of the station and photos of the people who worked there, with their name and position listed underneath, grouped as a school class would be. Photographs of the cable ships, AT&T cable landings, and maps of Guam decorate the walls. Due to the massive downsizings that have occurred since the 1980s, far fewer people work at Tanguisson today. The cable community, however, still exists.

Laid by AT&T in 1980, TAIGU provided an undersea telephone link between Guam and Taiwan, one indication of the growing American interest in developing telecommunications networks between the US and Asia.

Entering service in March 1999, this optical cable connects the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company’s station in Batangas with AT&T’s landing point in Guam, where connections are made to several Asia-U.S. networks. It was designed to complement and ease congestion along existing Asian and trans-Pacific cable systems.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Verizon Business,  AT&T,  KDDI,  Tata Communications,  China Telecom,  Chunghwa Telecom,  KT,  NTT,  Level 3,  SingTel,  Sprint,  Telekom Malaysia,  Telecom New Zealand,  Telstra,  PCCW,  LG Uplus,  Softbank Telecom,  Rostelecom,  SingTel Optus,  France Telecom

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: It’s a typical grey day in Nakhodka. Looking out across the bay, you see large shipping vessels lingering beyond the oil rigs that dot the shore. Discovered in 1859 by a Russian warship seeking shelter from a storm, Nakhodka means “lucky find.” Despite its location on the edge of Siberia, the bay is both calm and ice-free, making it an optimal location for dropping anchor, as well as for surfacing cable systems. Nakhodka was the site for the landing of a telephone cable to Japan in 1969, followed by several fiber-optic links carrying Internet traffic. As is true for many of the postwar systems, this station is a relocation, over 100 miles, from the previous urban telegraph cable landing in Vladivostok. Similarly, the Trans-Siberian railway’s eastern terminus was shifted to Nakhodka in the 1950s, when Soviet authorities closed Vladivostok to foreign shipping. Then the only open port in the Russian Far East, Nakhodka grew rapidly from its trade and communications industries. Today, the small city of 150,000 still supports circulations across the ocean: shipping and receiving, fish processing and canning, oil exports and cable transmissions.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Wikipedia contributors, “Nakhodka,” Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia, accessed June 9, 2013, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nakhodka.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Japan-Siberia cable (JASC), laid in 1969, was a true postwar international collaboration. The cable was manufactured in part by Japan's Ocean Cable Company and in part by the United States's Underseas Cable Corporation (all of whose previous cables had been supplied to the US military). The cable was then laid by both the Japanese ship KDD Maru with assistance from the Dutch Great Northern Telegraph Company. This kind of collaboration was a hallmark of the analogue era. It operated long beyond its system design life (which was only 20 years) up until 1996, when it was withdrawn from service and used for earthquake research.

In 1995, this optical line replaced the coaxial Japan Sea Cable between Japan and Russia, increasing capacity more than 300-fold and adding a link to Korea. Over a dozen companies invested in the project, including KDDI (Japan), Rostelecom (Russia), and AT&T. The cable fell out of use when the new Russia-Japan Cable Network came online in 2008.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Rostelecom,  KDDI

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1893, New Caledonia is changing. The prisoners have almost all left, and commerce is coming. A telegraph cable is being landed on New Caledonia’s soft shores. As you follow it inland, low brush and flowering bushes lead to dry meadows dotted with trees, providing little obstacle to signal traffic. Farther in, green and brown peaks soar upwards. Almost three decades earlier, nickel was discovered in these mountains, and since then the French have been mining the island. Despite their efforts at immigration, New Caledonia is now largely unpopulated by Europeans. Not long ago, the island was a French penal colony that held over 20,000 criminals and political prisoners. Many of them were Communards, punished for creating a self-governing socialist society in Paris. The cells emptied out when they were granted amnesty in 1879. With the discovery of nickel, this place began to serve a new purpose, and the French government hopes to establish itself in the South Pacific by making New Caledonia a hub. For now, there is but one route for telegraph signals: back and forth to Australia.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: ll Glover, “Australian Cables,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 22, 2013, http://www.atlantic-cable.com/CableCos/Australia/.
"Queensland-New Caledonia Cable, 1893-1923," National Archives of Australia, Brisbane Office, J2774 J2774/1, W11308.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1893-1898, as per Atlantic-Cable.com, or 1925, as per archival records in iPhoto

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The French company, La Societe Française des Télégraphes Sous-Marins, extended this cable from the Australian coast to New Caledonia in 1893, as part of a project to link France to its colonies.

From a nearly dead-stop traffic jam, you escape Phnom Penh and start down the road to Sihanoukville. Once dubbed the most dangerous road in Cambodia, National Highway 4 was constructed to connect the capital to the country’s largest seaport. Trucks piled with containers, themselves loaded with merchandise to be shipped abroad, speed down the two-lane highway in all conditions, veering into oncoming traffic to pass. Along the roadside are countless sweatshops secured by twelve-foot walls, places where handbags, socks, and garments of all kinds are manufactured. Small towns have sprung up around them, along with markets that sell the national beer and display advertisements for the Cambodian People’s Party. Water and sewage transit next to the roadside. The cables planned to connect the country, which as of 2014 still had no undersea links, will hook up to a fiber-optic cable along the road and cost the country millions of dollars. Like the infrastructures before it, they will accelerate the region’s economic development, for better or for worse.

You might have come here in 1871, when the China Submarine Telegraph Cable company surfaced a cable from Singapore. Or, you might have come along the 1884 cable, brought ashore by the Eastern Extension company. Despite these outlets to British Empire, Saigon remained in the hands of the French, who finally laid their own system at the turn of the twentieth century. Leaving the city, transmission was slow at times: the government controlled the cable station and international messages sent during times of conflict could be delayed for at least an hour in order for censors to approve them. The cable itself comes ashore far from Saigon, about 50 miles away in rural Cape St. James. A report from the local hydrographic office noted that “the station at Cape St. James was a more healthy place than Saigon, [but] it had some drawbacks,” including potential “incursions of wild beasts. Large tigers were constantly prowling in the vicinity of the station… That the danger was not imaginary was proved by the killing of a large tiger on the verandah of the telegraph station.” Although the area is now a sprawling city and home to over 300,000, it continues to be a critical cable hub, with lines extending out to sea just a few miles around the cape.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The French post and telegraph service extended a cable from Saigon to Poulo Condor, and onward to the Dutch East Indies in 1906. The cable, according to one report, was "part of a scheme for endowing France with a general system of submarine telegraphs which would free her from her dependence on the British system."

At Papenoo, you surface in an unlikely place: on the grounds of a local school. Until recently French Polynesia relied on wireless means of communication, but due to the scarcity of satellites in the South Pacific, the cost for bandwidth remained high for its approximately 270,000 residents. In 2010 the Honotua cable—stretching out across the ocean to Hawai‘i—was made possible by funding from the French government, granted as part of a measure to bridge the digital divide and extend broadband to all French citizens. Honotua was not seen simply as a technical bridge to a global network, but as emanating from local language and mythology. Ceremonies were staged at the cable landings, where men and women danced in traditional native attire. The cable was named in Tahitian: "hono" means a link and "tua" means the back, backbone, or far ocean. Legend has it that the link traces the route of the Tahitian Queen, who long ago lived at the cable landing site at Papenoo, and had traveled to the landing site at Hawai‘i. The company that laid the system learned of a second coincidence after the cable had already been named. The local mayor informed them that a man residing near the landing had a relative named Honotua, yet another connection of cable to local genealogy.

Annexed by Queensland in the 1880s, Papua New Guinea's capital has long been subject to Australian oversight. Yet while colonists maintained a military and administrative presence on the island, they provided few public works or services. The first cables were laid during the 1940s, but were not intended to carry indigenous communications. Instead, they served the Australian Navy. Stretching only a few kilometers out to sea, these armored cables served to detect the presence of Japanese submarines and predict potential invasions. Although the cables were dismantled after two years, Australia continued to administer the region until 1975, the year Papua New Guinea both gained independence and received its first transoceanic cable: APNG. Today, Port Moresby remains an important link in the chain between old and new forms of colonization. Corporations follow in the footsteps of colonial powers, pouring economic investments into the area, always with strings attached. ExxonMobil has begun a billion dollar liquid natural gas operation in the north of the country, creating undersea pipe networks that host both fuel and communications. The APNG-2 fiber-optic cable, one of Papua New Guinea’s newest transoceanic connections, surfaces on Ela Beach, following the exact path as its predecessors.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: David Fickling, “Raskol gangs rule world's worst city,” The Guardian, accessed June 22, 2013, http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2004/sep/22/population.davidfickling.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Telikom Papua New Guinea,  Telstra

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Port Alberni draws its wealth from the vast forest of British Columbia’s shores. Deep inland, sheltered from the Pacific Ocean by a long, narrow inlet, the town’s early dwellers worked at waterfront mills, stripping the woods around them to make products that circled the globe. By the 1960s, many residents worked for MacMillan Bloedel, one of the world’s largest forestry companies. It not only boosted the region’s economy, but created a social world. Each of its divisions had its own social club which organized gatherings of all kinds and structured local life. Yet in the 1960s and 70s, a new constituency began to oppose the logging of Vancouver Island. Environmentalists called for the protection of nature and the establishment of parks. When the first undersea telephone link, COMPAC, arrived in 1963, environmentalists clashed with the Canadian Overseas Telecommunications Service, since the company had cleared forest to make way for their system. As signals come ashore today, however, surfacing amidst logs and swerving uphill next to the Alberni Plywood Division, they face little resistance.

Dairen, Manchuria is today’s Dalian, China. This port city sits on a peninsula that juts out into the Yellow Sea, bisecting the Chinese mainland and North Korea, and threading together the region’s histories of communications and transport. At the time of its first cable landing, this piece of land was under Russian control. When war with Japan broke out in 1904, the Japanese quickly took control of Dairen and brought in their own telegraph cables. In the years that followed, the war-ravaged city was rebuilt as a "modern colonial showcase" by its new rulers. Extensive planning went into Dairen's green spaces: parks, shaded avenues, and thousands of Acacia trees transformed what many had thought of as a "shabby port town" into a "beacon of civilization." As part of the effort to clean up Dairen, planners segregated neighborhoods, keeping the thousands of migrant Chinese workers apart from Japanese residents. And, in tune with other infrastructure developments, new broadcasting facilities were established to spread Japanese culture and propaganda across the airwaves.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: “Dairen: History,” Manchurian Legacy: Memoirs of a Japanese Colonist, accessed, July 28, 2013, http://www.manchurianlegacy.com/dairen.htm.
Julean Arnold et al, Department of Commerce, “Chefoo Consular District,” in Commercial Handbook of China, Volume 1 (Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 1919), 464-465.

Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1901-1950,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed July 28, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1901.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Japanese Government laid this system in 1904, in line with their expanding territorial ambitions at the turn of the twentieth century.

As part of a growing desire for greater sovereignty over its telecommunications network, Japan laid the majority of this cable in 1908, linking the nation to Manchurian China. This extended their communications network well into Chinese territory, and picked up where Russian influence had been waning in the wake of the Russo-Japanese War.
In 1921, the Japanese Government laid a cable from Nagasaki, its cable hub closest to Asia, to Dairen.

In the early 1890s, two major infrastructures latched Medan into global networks: the Port of Belawan and an undersea communications cable. Only seventy years before, Medan had been a village of only 200, but in the intervening years it quickly expanded as a center of trade. Massive amounts of tobacco were harvested from Dutch plantations and shipped out of Medan’s port, including the much-desired Deli leaf for cigar wrapping. When tobacco farming pushed the soil’s limits, American companies created rubber plantations, some encompassing tens of thousands of acres. At one point, the United States Rubber Company held 150 square miles of land and employed fourteen thousand indentured laborers. The social and environmental ramifications of the plantations were huge. Large swathes of forest were cleared by Chinese and native laborers, the rural peasantry was left without land, and chemical fertilizers were spread across the ground. Though the city is no longer under Dutch rule, the colonial infrastructure had a lasting impact. Plantation-financed colonial architecture remains, and coffee, rubber, and palm oil estates continue to devastate the forests. Enormous container ships load their exports at the Port of Belawan, now the second busiest port in Indonesia. And undersea cables, as in the nineteenth century, link Medan’s economy and culture into a global system.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1951-2000,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 22, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1951.htm.

Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed July 13, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
“Port of Belawan, North Sumatera, Indonesia,” accessed July 13, 2013, http://seaport.homestead.com/files/belawan.html.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This cable was strung between Pantai Cermin, Medan, Indonesia, and Penang, Malaysia in 1984.

Built during a momentary pause in Dutch military aggression, this cable linked the independent city and sultanate of Aceh with the Dutch colony further down the Malacca Strait. As Dutch agents moved through Aceh, studying and testing regional political ties, the cable likely provided a secure means for intelligence reporting.

This 1985 coaxial cable network connected Singapore to France by way of the Indian Ocean. It was a massive undertaking involving 21 different countries and, measuring 13,585 km in length, it was the longest telephone cable of its time. It served for 14 years until the introduction of SeaMeWe-2’s fiber network made it redundant.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: On a desolate road in Western Borneo, you hear dogs whining and the cry of a newborn child. Watch out, the Malaysians would tell you, this is the pontianak, the vampiric ghost of a mother who died in childbirth. According to local legend, when Arab adventurer Syarif Abdurrahman Alkadrie ignored indigenous warnings and settled here in 1771, he was haunted by the pontianak. Undeterred, he established a Sultanate, and built a mosque, a fort, and a coastal trading station amidst the swamplands. Chinese immigrants transited through Pontianak, and some settled, trading gold mined from Borneo’s mountains. The Arab ruler also welcomed the Dutch, setting the stage for colonial expansion in the region. Even after Pontianak became a protectorate of the Dutch East Indies, it remained a place of encounter and conflict between these diverse ethnic groups. At the turn of the 20th century, the Dutch allied with another colonial power, the French, to make Pontianak a connecting point between cables to Batavia and French Indochina. Unlike the city's varied inhabitants, these links did not have such long lasting effects. It was not until a century later, in 2006, that the next cable landed here, a fiber-optic one linking out to Batam and Jakarta.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1901-1950,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed September 8, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1901.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Tschifu is today called Yantai, meaning “smoky tower.” In a way, this harbor town was always a critical communications node: the name refers back to the Ming Dynasty, when locals would light smoky fires to warn the village of approaching Japanese pirates. On the northeastern tip of the Shandong Peninsula, Tschifu was directly south of Dairen, due west of Seoul, and straight north from Shanghai. Its central location made it an ideal cable hub during the telegraph era. In the first decade of the twentieth century, ten cables were landed here, primarily by the British and the Germans, connecting to Tsingtau, Port Arthur, Taku, Dairen, Shanghai, and Wei-hai-wei. Even before the cables were landed, the city had long been an important traffic hub: it had been an international trading port for almost half a century and the home to embassies of seventeen nations.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 1, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Australasia and China Telegraph Company, “a purely British enterprise,” laid cable along the same path as their German rivals in 1900, even employing the same Dutch cable ship. Yet, as one Brit noted, “Our communications with our own folk must be independent of private companies and completely independent of all foreign nations.”

Growing in importance following the Boxer Rebellion, the German cable system in China sought to maintain its impressive international network and to profit from the growing international need for communications. In the process, Tsingtau “has been converted into a charming town of officalism,” notes the Japan Weekly Mail, who did not shy from expressing its own colonial interests in the region.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1900-?; German PTT             Sherard Osborn           2 cables laid over this route. CS Von Podbielski loaded the cable aboard at Rotterdam. Opened for traffic on the 4th October 1900 (See AtlanticCable.com)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Danish ship CS Sherard Osborn, on behalf of Administration of Posts of the German Empire, laid German-manufactured cables from the free port of Tsingtau to both Tschifu and Shanghai in 1900. In the process Tsingtau was connected to the Great Northern Telegraph network, and the German telegraph service took an important step towards completing its global cable loop.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1900-?; Telcon; Eastern Extension, Australasia and China Telegraph Company    Store Nordiske (1); (see AtlanticCable.com)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Used by the British as a summer anchorage for the Royal Navy’s China Station and as a health resort, Wei-Hai-Wei was leased to the Queen in 1898 for use in the maintenance of colonial affairs. Although the 1900 cable was initially laid out of a raised concern for reliable communications with Chinese regions following the Boxer Uprising, it also proved to be a vital link to journalists covering the Russo-Japanese War.

Laid by the Danish Great Northern Telegraph Company in 1900, the Tschifu-Taku line was part of a larger set of ventures that stemmed from a contract offered by the Russian government to establish telegraph connections with China, Japan, and Hong Kong. The cables’ immediate need, however, was to be found in response to the “Boxer troubles” brewing in the Asian continent.

The Tschifu-Taku cable, laid in 1900, soon found itself in the center of military conflict. “The reason for the probable isolation of Che-Foo consists in the fact that it is only connected with the main line by loops. The junction is inland at Chin-Ing, and Boxers are believed to be in that neighborhood. If they are successful their first step is sure to be the destruction of the line.”

Following the strategic destruction of telegraph lines in Tschifu during the Boxer Uprising, the German Post Office laid cable once more along the Bohai Sea in 1901 to reestablish its network. This restoration, along with that of the railroad, was conducted amid the watchful presence of the foreign armies of the Eight-Nation Alliance.

The Russian post and telegraph service laid this cable from Port Arthur to Tschifu. Only five years later, the cable was handed over to the Imperial Chinese Telegraph Company. Subsequently, Japan  signed a treaty with China to operate the system.

Although Weihaiwei’s name refers to its historic role as a military stronghold (wei), this city has long been a haven from conflicts in the region. The town features a natural harbor, steep mountain surroundings, and two miles of fortified walls built to guard against Japanese pirate raids. However, these defenses failed in 1895 when it was occupied briefly by Japan during the First Sino-Japanese War. After foreign troops withdrew, the lease to the town was awarded to Britain in order to counter-balance Japan’s and Russia’s incursions into Northern China. As a result, from 1898 until 1930 the town was occupied by British administrators and provided summer anchorage for the Royal Navy. Although they kept it as an active port, the British didn’t invest nearly as much here as in cities such as Shanghai. No stamps were issued, British currency was not circulated, and full colonial law was never enacted. This was especially true after the Russo-Japanese War, when Shandong Province was controlled primarily by Germany. Weihaiwei’s cable network, used to relay news of the shifting balance of power in the North back to Hong Kong, provided strategic insight for Britain that surpassed the town’s potential as a colony.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Along the shores of the Pearl River, across from Hong Kong, Macau was a fishing village until Portuguese traders, seeking a place to dry and store goods, established themselves there in the mid-16th century. Commodities were not the only things traded: in the same period Macau was a key node in the trafficking of Chinese slaves to Portugal. Even after the enslavement of the Chinese was outlawed, slavery remained an ever-present part of social life. In the early 1600s, there were approximately 6 slaves, the majority of whom had been brought from Africa, for every Portuguese family. Portuguese shacks grew only gradually into a settlement, and it was not until after the opium wars of the 19th century that China ceded the right of governance and occupation in exchange for a promise that Portugal would assist in levying a tax on the drug. Only a few years before, in 1884, a telegraph cable linked Macau to Hong Kong, across the bay. The island remained under Portuguese control until 1999, making it the last remaining European colony in Asia. That year, it was both transferred back to China, and linked via a modern undersea cable system, SEA-WE-ME-3, which revived the earlier connection to Hong Kong.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Like so many Indonesian cities, Makassar developed under the influence of European spice trades beginning in the 16th century. The Dutch came in the 17th century and the cables began to arrive in the late 19th century, connecting this city with Bali in 1888, Balikpapan in 1905, and then with Java and Central Sulawesi in 1913. Arriving along the cable at the turn of the twentieth century, you witness the height of Dutch development: they had captured, rebuilt, and renamed the city’s central fort. The new “Fort Rotterdam” looked very much like its namesake, with manicured lawns and large stone buildings with pitched red roofs. The walled city that developed around the fort was a hub for the copra, rattan, pearls, trepang, and sandalwood trade, and enslaved local people for businessmen. Although Joseph Conrad called Makassar “the prettiest and perhaps, cleanest looking of all the towns in the islands,” such beauty reflected colonial interests.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1905, Norddeutsche Seekabelwerke, Dutch East Indies Government

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: After the Boer War, the British government often searched and detained both ships and communications from neutral parties, including the Dutch. This undersea cable, laid on behalf of the Dutch government of the East Indies in 1881, was seen as essential to the the privacy and expediency of colonial communications.

In the 1920s, a submarine cable manufactured by the German company Norddeutsche Seekabelwerke and sponsored by the Dutch East Indies government was laid down the western coast of Sulawesi, connecting Dutch settlements on the island to Surabaya.

On December 31, 1870, Madras, India (the colonial name for the city now known as Chennai) received its first underwater telegraph line, which linked India to Malaysia. The telegraph station in Madras was connected in the other direction to overland lines, controlled by the Indian government, reaching across the subcontinent to Bombay. One of the last British ports to be developed, Madras lacked a proper harbor until 1890. Due to the city’s shallow coastal plain, ships had to offload cargo from nearly a quarter mile out to sea, and only then when waters were calm. When the Telcon cable ship arrived, recounts an Australian crewmember, rafts and surfboats were used to bring the line close to the beach before it was “hauled on shore by natives through the surf which is heavy there.” A successful test of the Madras-Penang connection was celebrated with a dinner on the ship and, later that evening, a New Year’s Eve party at the Madras town hall “to which we were all invited, it was a grand affair.”

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Surfacing at Whitford Beach, you are careful not to be hit by one of the sixteen-foot tall waves also making its way to the shore. This beach is beautiful and active: the hollow and powerful waves draw surfers from throughout the area and the soft sands bring visitors to lounge, fly kites, and ride horses along this sunny stretch of land. Several major international cables have also landed here, connecting Australia to Asia. About ten miles inland is the Perth International Telecommunications Centre (PITC), which occupies 710 square acres of flat, dry land in a rural suburb. Since 1986, the center has handled much of Australia's signal traffic. With its own power plant, and a 15-meter diameter antenna for communicating with spacecrafts, PITC is a stark contrast to the brick house on the shores of Cottesloe that welcomed the trans-Indian-Ocean telegraph cable in 1901.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Southwest of Dairen, at the tip of the Liaodong Peninsula, Port Arthur was an important Russian naval base at the turn of the twentieth century. Valued in part because of its southern location and naturally protected harbor, the port gave the Russians year-round, ice-free access to the Pacific. The development of the port was only one part of a massive infrastructural expansion. The area served as a coaling station for the Russian fleet and a termination point for rail networks across the continent. In 1900, the Russians brought two telegraph cables ashore, one connecting south across the Yellow Sea to Tschifu, China and one connecting the longer distance west to Sasebo. This communications node would soon become Russia’s Achilles’ Heel: the cables were cut and intercepted by the Japanese leading up to and during the Russo-Japanese War. Unable to receive reports or warnings, Port Arthur was then surprised when Japanese ships attacked. The Japanese took control of the port and from here were able to wage a successful war for the control of Manchurian land and sea. Unrest may have started even earlier, however: in the year before the war, cable ships record trips to repair breaks in the Port Arthur – Tschifu cable, due to “willful cutting.”

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Alongside a cable to Tschifu, the Russian post and telegraph service laid a cable from Port Arthur to Sasebo, in Japan. With the loss of the Russo-Japanese war, the Russians lost not only the port, but their cables.

A century ago, Yap was a Pacific communications hub, the junction point of three cables linking Guam, Shanghai, and Manado. Colonized by Germany, it was a critical node in their vast cable network of over 18,000 miles. Yap also formed an important bridge between America and China. From Guam, the United States relied on the German-Netherlands network to connect to Shanghai. During World War I, the Japanese seized the island and Yap became not only a “cable threat,” but a threat to the sea route between the U.S. and the Philippines. After the war, the possession of Yap, its cables, and its coaling station was the subject of a dispute between the United States and Japan. Japan claimed that the island had been designated to her under a Mandate of the League of Nations. The United States sought to put Yap under “International supervision” as an international cable station, rather than under control of a single nation. After a year of deadlock, the United States and Japan came to an agreement that split the network, and subsequently eliminated all cable links. Today, Yap remains without cable systems and without high-speed Internet infrastructure, linked only via wireless technologies. A single satellite station carries all of Yap’s Internet traffic out of the country.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1942, Japan diverted a German cable (originally laid in 1905 between Menado, Yap, and Guam) to Palau, where it had military installations and regional government headquarters from 1914 to 1944.

Menado derives from the word "manadou" or "wanazou," meaning “on the far coast” or “in the distance.” The town is located on the far northwestern tip of the Indonesian island Sulawesi. The Dutch East India Company built a fortress here in 1658 and from that time it was slowly and steadily colonized and Christianized by traders and missionaries. The thick stone walls of the city’s fort still exist, but outside it, the town grew into a colonial village with hedgerows, streets, gardens, and cottages. In 1905, traveling via Menado’s first undersea cable, you traverse a busy port filled with large trading vessels and smaller, slimmer pinisiq, Indonesian sailboats. The beautiful bay actually makes a bad harbor: the reefs and steep slope in the sea floor provide little anchorage. Between the cable landing and the distant mountaintops, expansive coffee plantations dot the landscape. Although it will never grow into a sizeable port city, this location will remain important to the Dutch in part due to its massive coffee exports.

Covering roughly 650 miles, the cable was deployed by sister ships Restorer and Patrol, launched from England that year and sold for scrap to the Japanese only a decade later.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Lacking a large-scale cable laying fleet, the Dutch contracted other nations – any nation but Britain – to help outfit their colonial territories with modern undersea cables. This line, laid in 1913, was completed by the German company Norddeutsche Seekabelwerke.

Mauritius been a small but important stopping point for traffic across the Indian Ocean. Its visitors never merely pass through – they always leave something behind. In the 1600s, when the island became a waypoint for Dutch ships, generations of sailors and settlers left invasive species that devastated the local ecosystem. The flightless dodo bird and the domed giant tortoise were among the animals to disappear. When the French took possession of Mauritius in 1700s, they set up lucrative sugar plantations and brought in slaves from nearby Madagascar and Africa. And when the British colonized the island a century later, they replaced slavery with a system of indentured servitude, importing thousands of laborers from India. A telegraph cable was brought to the island shortly thereafter, and Mauritius became a stopping point for colonial dispatches between Europe, Africa and Asia. Although Mauritius has been an independent state since 1968, the former pathways of colonial powers have left their mark here: a diverse, multi-ethnic population, a connection point for transoceanic travelers, and a hub for communications infrastructure. Today, fiber-optic networks link to the edges of the island and data centers are nested in its interior.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: One legend has it that “Kinabalu,” the name of the tallest mountain in the Malay archipelago, is derived from the words for “Chinese Widow.” Long ago, a Chinese prince married a local Kadazan woman, and when he departed for China, he promised to return. She waited for him atop the mountain, where eventually she was turned to stone. In its early years Kota Kinabalu, then named Jesselton, depended heavily upon travelers from the sea. From Jesselton, ships and trains relayed goods with the help of both the British North Borneo Company, who administered the area, and Chinese merchants that funneled products to markets in mainland Asia. Undersea cables, though, bypassed Jesselton to link directly to the more prominent Labuan. Following World War II, when almost all of the city’s architecture and infrastructure was decimated, the town was reconstructed as the capital of North Borneo, which in 1963 gained independence. Major development initiatives were launched in this period, including the SEACOM undersea cable, which connected the city to Singapore and Hong Kong only a year afterward. Today Kota Kinabalu remains the economic and industrial capital of its state.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This cable was launched on October 19, 1992, with a press conference at the Philippine Plaza Hotel in Manila. It was part of the $320 million ASEAN Optical-Fiber Submarine Cable Network, which also included lines between Brunei and Singapore, and between two parts of Malaysia across the South China Sea.

The island of Billiton (the old Dutch spelling of Belitung) was a valuable site of tin extraction in the colonial era. Dutch mining operations started in the mid-1800s with the formation of the Billiton Company, named after the island. The company imported thousands of Chinese indentured laborers to perform the heavy and dangerous work in the mines. In the early 1900s, the Dutch East Indies government brought two submarine cables to Billiton’s capital city of Tanjung Pandan, connecting it to colonies in Java, Borneo, and Sumatra. Only a decade later, however, the capital was looted and set ablaze in a worker’s revolt. Belitung and the neighboring island of Bangka are still key points in the global tin trade. The Guardian estimates that in 2012 they produced 90% of the tin in Indonesia, an extraordinary amount given that Indonesia is the second-largest producer of the metal in the world. Environmental advocates recently launched a campaign against Microsoft, a company that uses tin in the production of electronics, accusing them of ignoring the ecological impacts of mining on the island.

The first and last submarine link to connect Infanta was landed in 1990. Known as the “gateway to the Pacific,” this medium-sized port city is located on a tiny peninsula that juts into the Polillo Strait, leading to the Philippine Sea. In the 1990s, the city led a double life as a manufacturing center for the province and a quiet escape destination. Straw-roofed resort huts dot the blue-green waters. The city itself sprawls inward with two-story buildings housing banks, offices, shops, and restaurants. Farther inland, logging sites and salt flats ship their spoils to the town. More recently, the city literally had to dig out from natural disaster: a monsoon in 2004 set off a mudslide in the nearby mountains, burying Infanta in millions of cubic meters of mud, water, cut logs, and uprooted trees. The cable escaped the catastrophe, having gone out of service just a year before.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Originally named Yangon in the 1700s, “end of strife” in Burmese, the city’s name was perverted to “Rangoon” under colonial rule. Under supervision of the British, Rangoon was built to be a political center and commercial hub, with trade ships traveling almost twenty miles down its river to the Gulf of Martaban. When a cable was brought ashore in 1877, connecting the city to Penang, Rangoon was a gridded, western-style city, with sprawling parks, wealthy suburbs, lakes, and hospitals. The telegraph office was established in a large, four story red brick building with ionic columns marking the entrance. Although the British rule ceased in 1948, following great strife and a protracted struggle for independence, the building still stands today. Myanmar's first and, as of 2015, only fiber-optic link, lands about 75 miles south in coastal Pyapon. As in the colonial era, however, Yangon’s inclusion in the cable system is heavily dependent on external support: it is only one small stop in a globe-spanning network.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Electric Beach, on O‘ahu’s west shore, is named for the large power plant towering behind it and known for regular car burglaries. Three men casually fish off the edge of the point. Families barbeque. A manhole is covered in rusty red dirt. Moving under this manhole, through the cable, and out to the ocean, you briefly pass a small cave with hanging clothes, stockpiled chairs, and collected water. The same beach that makes possible the landing of communications cables – infrastructures that accelerate the movement of information across the oceans – is also a temporary dwelling for some of the least mobile Hawaiians. The Kahe Point station, constructed just north of Electric Beach, has managed to stay out of view, and therefore out of local politics.

Long before Bandon became AT&T’s outpost in rural Oregon, it was a critical node in an undersea cable network: the U.S. military’s Sound Surveillance System (SOSUS). From the Pacific coast, SOSUS connected hydrophones and picked up sonic traces of subaquatic movements, from the deployment of Soviet submarines to migrations of whales. Officers stationed at Naval Facility Coos Head tuned into these underwater listening posts and collected data on enemy operations. The Coos Head facility, first opened in 1958, was closed twenty-nine years later in 1987. Improvements in signal-processing had replaced manpower with computers, and as the Cold War wound down the number of Naval Facilities was reduced. Given AT&T’s tight ties with the U.S. Navy, and their assistance in developing SOSUS, it was unsurprising when nine years later, they chose Bandon as a landing point for their newest transpacific cable system, TPC-5.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Huế is a watery city. Located in the center of the Vietnamese coast, its harbors and lagoons are protected by narrow strips of land that separate them from the South China Sea. The flat, grey-green Perfume River winds inland for a few miles, where it meets a matrix of canals flowing through the heart of the city. In the 17th century, the Nguyen Lords established the seat of their empire here, in a closed citadel on the north side of the river, from which they governed most of southern Vietnam. Everywhere there are monuments to the city’s prominence over the centuries: old tombs of emperors, ancient grey stone gates, carved statues, and brightly colored pagodas. At the beginning of the 1800s, Huế was captured by Emperor Gia Long and made capital of all of Vietnam. It was not until the city became a “French protectorate,” later in the 19th century, that it was linked by its first undersea cable.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 16, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The island is an unwelcoming place, and a center of conflict. Anton Chekov described it quite simply as “hell.” Peopled mostly by soldiers and life-long prisoners, with a few fishermen, Alexandrovsk-Sakhalinsky is damp, cold, and icy in the winter months. A small harbor town on the island of Sakhalin, off the edge of the Russian mainland and north of the northernmost part of Japan, it became the location of a Russian military post in 1881, established to oversee the prison camps and nearby exile settlements. Political dissidents, criminals, and ethnic minorities were sent to live here in large communal cells and to work the land for the rest of their lives. Chekov lived here in 1890 while working on a treatise about the Tsarist penal system. Arriving before the completion of the Trans-Siberian railroad or the trans-Pacific cable, he traveled the 6,000 miles across Siberia by coach, and then across the water by boat to the island. He wrote of his arrival: "Along the shore near the pier some 50 convicts were wandering, obviously idle; some wore overalls, others in jackets or grey cloth coats. When I approached, they removed their caps.  It is possible that no writer has ever previously received such an honour." Fifteen years later, during the Russo-Japanese war, the southern half of the island would be taken by the Japanese and united with the island of Hokkaido by a submarine communications cable.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: “From Siberia,” and “Across the Tatar Strait,” Sakhalin Island's Notes, accessed August 29, 2013, https://www.facebook.com/pages/Sakhalin-Island/186207661398058?sk=notes.

Bryan Walsh, “Postcard from Sakhalin Island: Hell Frozen Over is Red Hot Again,” Time.com, August 14, 2007, accessed August 5, 2013, http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1653033,00.html.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1905, following the Russo-Japanese war, the Japanese laid a line from the northern tip of Japan to Sakhalin Island.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: On AtlanticCable.com, many landings indicated by "Mogi, Nagasaki-ken, Japan"

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Like many port cities in Asia, Nagasaki was “discovered” by imperial powers – in this case, the Portuguese – and developed for trade. In the nineteenth century, Nagasaki became a busy transit point, with a vibrant ship-building industry, an anchorage site for the Japanese navy, and a telegraph cable landing point. Three years after its first submarine telegraph cable was landed in 1871, the telegraph company established a headquarters here, in a large two-story office building abutting the harbor. Within a few years, Japan would build up its internal landlines, and the country would be connected to the rest of the world via Nagasaki. The importance of this station was clear to Japan and its enemies. Described as “clutching the aeortic artery of international communications in Japan,” Nagasaki, as a hub and military harbor, was also a target. The cable to Vladivostok was taken out of service during the Russo-Japanese War, but the city remained undamaged. During World War II, however, Nagasaki was hit with the atomic bomb, the second and last to ever be deployed, killing several hundred thousand people. After the Japanese surrender, the city would slowly rebuild. Old communications lines were taken out of service, and new coaxial cables laid in their place.

“Umegasaki Stories,” Nagasaki: People, Places and Scenes of the Nagasaki Foreign Settlement 1859-1941, accessed August 10, 2013, http://www.nfs.nias.ac.jp/page007.html.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Japanese Government linked Nagasaki with Taiwan in 1910, extending the domain under Imperial control.
The Japanese Military connected Nagasaki and Tsingtau in 1914.
In 1917, the Japanese Government extended a second link from Nagasaki to Taiwan.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: At the request of the Japanese government, the Great Northern Telegraph Company laid the first cable under the Korean Strait in 1883. The cable linked Nagasaki via Japan’s Tsushima Island to Pusan (now officially spelled Busan), the first international port in Korea and a major Japanese settlement.

In the 10th century, tall pagodas were erected to protect Fuzhou from the “evil influences of atmospheric currents.” These currents brought more human trouble than atmospheric calamity, however, as Fuzhou proved to be a critical site in the contestation and violent defense of British opium sales. After taking China to war in order to secure their access to regional markets, Britain opened the port, then called Foochow, to foreign contact and trade for the first time in centuries. Tea was exported from the country through Fuzhou in massive quantities while European technologies and opiates alike crossed its shores. More recently, the area has been opened to foreign circulations in other ways. As fiber-optics replace the colonial cables laid in its harbor, the Chinese government has iteratively marked parts of Fuzhou as industrial free trade zones, opening its borders to foreign investment without taxation. As a part of the “Maritime Silk Road” the port presently hosts operations from 93 of the global Fortune 500 companies.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Ben Ross, “Coming to America…Fuzhou’s Main Export is People,” Urban Sociology and Urbanism, in China and North America, accessed September 12, 2013, http://benross.net/wordpress/illegal-immigration/2007/05/22/.

Rev. Stephen Livingstone Baldwin, “A Trip to China,” Frank Leslie’s Popular Monthly xviii (July-December, 1884), accessed September 9, 2013, http://www.gnudoyng.net/christianity/1884_foo-chow.php.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This cable, laid under the direction of Danish engineer Emanuel Hansen, completed the first electric link between Taiwan and China. In China, it was landed at the mouth of the Min River, in Foochow in 1888.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Jonathan Manthorpe, Forbidden Nation: A History of Taiwan (New York: Palgrave Macmillan, 2005), 147.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The only station on the west coast of Honshu, Naoetsu was linked to Russia by coaxial cable in 1969, followed by optical lines in the 1990s and 2000s. But this was not the town’s first entry into exchange networks. As early as the ninth century, its harbor bustled with merchant ships carrying rice, salted salmon, and fabrics for protection against the wet and snowy climate, later expanding to accommodate steamships and cargo vessels. Naoetsu is also the birthplace of Maejima Hisoka, Japan’s first Minister of Communications and so-called father of the postal system. After studying British mail delivery in 1870, he returned to Japan and set up a network of sixty-five offices between Tokyo and Osaka. By 1881, there were more than five thousand.

Heading inland to the Makaha cable station, you surface in a parking lot, in a manhole barely visible under the dirt. Along the beaches to the south of this town reside hundreds of houseless people. O‘ahu’s west shore is home to one of the state’s largest native communities and largest homeless population. In Makaha alone, 32% of its residents live in poverty. Yet, the west shore is also a transit point for a large percentage of the state’s international signal traffic. Since the 1960s, almost all of the island’s coaxial and fiber-optic cables have terminated at three cable stations along this short 30-kilometer stretch. The seemingly divergent histories of telecommunications success and economic deprivation in the area are intertwined, and linked to the area's long-standing military occupation. Weapons testing sites and military installations, such as the Lualualei Naval Reservation and the Schofield Barracks, displaced residents from the west shore’s inland valleys. At the same time, the U.S. military was once one of the biggest customers of the cable networks, giving them both an economic boost and a layer of protection when they were set up during the Cold War.

Midway between Taiwan and China, this chain of small islands is strategically important. As a result, even though they are sparsely populated, the Penghu Islands have long been linked to communications networks. In the late 1880s, at the order of the Qing governor of Taiwan, a telegraph cable connected Penghu to China in the east and Taiwan to the west. This was accompanied by gun emplacements meant to fortify the “militarily indispensible” island. Despite these measures, less than ten years later the islands were ceded to Japan along with Taiwan, a result of China’s defeat in the Sino-Japanese war. The Japanese would remain in Penghu throughout the first half of the twentieth century, laying cables that linked across the Taiwan Strait. While the connected cities grew busy with international trade, the Penghu Islands remained apart from the action, with most ships and signal traffic merely passing through. Today, the islands are linked to the rest of Taiwan via another kind of subsea technology: major undersea power cables link Penghu into Taiwan’s electric grid.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1901-1950,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 19, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1901.htm.
Jonathan Manthorpe, Forbidden Nation: A History of Taiwan (New York: Palgrave MacMillan, 2009), 147.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Liu Ming-Chuan, Qing governor of Taiwan, ordered the construction of this telegraph cable. It was part of a larger modernizing effort and ethos of self-sufficiency in the newly established Chinese province after a prolonged conflict with France. Completed in 1887, the line was laid by Taiwan’s first cable ship, the Feicheu.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Jonathan Manthorpe, Forbidden Nation: A History of Taiwan (New York: Palgrave Macmillan, 2005), 147.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Laid in 1917 between Taiwan and the Penghu Islands, this cable was a part of a concerted program of infrastructure development during Japanese colonial rule. These networks were essential to maintaining control over its colonies, especially after the Tapani uprising of 1915.

Laid in mid-1938, this Taiwanese-Chinese link came into operation in the midst of growing conflict between the China and Japan. Foreign colonialists and businessmen reporting on the region worried both about civilian casualties and well as falling telegraph prices between the warring countries.

Towards the end of the fiber-optic cable boom in the early 2000s, Tyco Telecommunications built a station in the town of Ma‘ili, seeking to tap into the torrent of information flow through O‘ahu’s west shore. It is located in the center of the town, next to an elementary school. Children play next door, their voices filtering across the lawn, over heaps of trash in an adjacent lot, and through the cable station. Yet during the cable bust, the plans collapsed and the building was put up for sale. Today, the station is abandoned and has bullet holes in its windows. No signals terminate here.

In 1917, following a fire at their cable station on New Zealand’s South Island, the Eastern Extension company re-located their links to Titahi Bay, on the North Island. The nature of the company and the culture of the station changed with this move. There was no need to physically man the coastal cable house. Here, the circuits were automatically switched once they came ashore and messages were routed directly to Wellington. Cable work no longer took place in a rural outpost, but in Eastern Extension’s office at the center of the city. Given the World War unfolding at the time, this shift to a population hub seemed to make the cable more secure. Along with the technology of automatic transmission, however, it drastically changed the culture of tight-knit cable operators.

The broad, low beaches of Broome, Australia made for an easy cable landing, but were less hospitable to the British men who operated it. Heavy heat made labor difficult, white ants consumed wooden walls, and there was no town with the comforts of civilization. One cableman reflected that this was indeed a “pioneering experience.” Without the assistance of local Aboriginal tribes, the importation of servants from abroad, and the regular call of supply ships, signal traffic would have stopped along the cable to Java. Some of the most arduous work, such as the construction of the men’s quarters, was given to the Chinese workmen. White ant-proof planks shipped in from Borneo were “anti-ant, anti-tool, and anti-Chinese patience,” recalls a cableman, but “proved so hard as to be almost unworkable.” Much later, when the Chinese servants refused to work, the British and their Malaysian crew armed themselves with revolvers and handcuffs, assuring that station operations would continue. Offshore, on the pearling boats that formed Broome’s most prominent industry, similar practices ensured. Here, Aboriginal women were enslaved and forced to dive for pearls, placing their lives at risk. In Broome, the entrance into a global network, whether via the circulation of messages or pearls, depended heavily on the exploitation of people.

As you approach Colombo, Ceylon (present-day Sri Lanka) in 1903, your travel guide tells you: “its appearance is extremely picturesque: a fine undulating country, well wooded to the water’s edge and fringed by cocoa-nut trees; lofty verdant ranges tower in the distance, covered with groves of talipat and other palms.” Centrally positioned in the Indian Ocean, Colombo was a key trade port long before the colonial era. In the early 1500s, the Portuguese established a fort and trading post to capitalize on the island’s abundant cinnamon crops. After a brief Dutch occupation, Colombo was ceded to the British and became the capital of British Ceylon. To facilitate faster communication to London, a submarine cable was brought to the island via the Middle East in 1913, connecting to a new Central Telegraph Office in a three-story wood building near the harbor. Messages could now travel between the two cities in as little as thirty minutes, a savings of nearly four hours compared to older land-based routes through India. Today, messages transit in only milliseconds from five cable systems that land in the Colombo area.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: If you could climb up the deep green mountains on the northern end of this island, and look west across the water, you would see the hills of the Korean peninsula rising above Pusan. A small island, about 700 square kilometers of land, Tsushima is equidistant between the Japanese mainland and Korea. Because of its location, it had been a trade center for centuries before the cables arrived, and since has been a perfect locale for international cable connections as well as strategic military operations. Five different cables have landed here since 1891. In 1905, during the Russo-Japanese War, a decisive battle was fought in the waters around the island, which the Japanese won largely through their adeptness with wireless telegraphy. Yet this did not lead to the scrapping of “older” cable systems. Quite the opposite. After the war, the Japanese immediately laid a new undersea telegraph cable: wires complement, rather than replace, wireless.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1933 the Japanese government laid a cable across the Sea of Japan, linking Tsushima with mainland Korea. At this time Korea was formally annexed by Japan, yet host to an insurgent provisional government that was fighting to resist Japanese control. The cable’s implementation followed a series of repressive Japanese policies targeting public communications, including the banning of the Korean language from schools and newspapers.

When it was completed in December 1937, the submarine cable between Fukuoka and Pusan became part of the longest carrier telephone line in service. From Fukuoka, the six-channel cable ran over the Japanese mainland to Tokyo, and from Pusan, it extended north through Korea and into the Manchukuo region of China, covering a total of more than 2,000 miles. The cable not only improved the quality of commercial telephone calls between Japan and the continent, but also expanded Japanese military communications in the lead-up to the Second World War.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:
Anton A. Huurdeman, The Worldwide History of Telecommunications. Hoboken, NJ: John Wiley & Sons, 2003. 327.
Daqing Yang, Technology of Empire: Telecommunications and Japanese Expansion in Asia, 1883-1945. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 2010. 165-9.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Today, Wakkanai is the northernmost city in Japan, with one of the island’s colder climates and record snowfalls totaling over 250 inches in a year. Yet a century ago the Japanese empire stretched even further north to the 50th parallel on the island of Sakhalin, taken from the Russians during the Russo-Japanese war. Wakkanai was a strategic outpost connecting the two islands and a submarine cable was laid to carry communications between their shores. After the Russians took back Sakhalin during World War II, forcing refugees south into Wakkanai, the city remained a strategic site. The United States’ Wakkanai Air Station, established shortly after the war, used radar installations to gather intelligence during the Cold War. Only miles from Sakhalin, and not far from the border between Russia and China, the listening post amassed information about critical events in the region for decades, pre-figuring the covert collection of data today by the National Security Agency and others.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1901-1950,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 10, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1901.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: On some islands, even finding a shore on which to land one’s cable is a fraught process. Located about 1,000 miles south east of Japan, the Bonin Islands have steep coastlines that make landing difficult. Rocky mountainsides rise up from the blue-green sea, gradually turning from stone into lush greenery higher in the sky. In some spots, small strips of sand slice between the ocean and the hills. In the early 1900s, a cable landed on one of these remote beaches, connecting Guam (and thereby the United States) to Japan. The Japanese had claimed the land only a few decades earlier, and about forty settlers made their homes on the previously uninhabited islands. An American company sent British ships and workers here to land the cable, all of whom were tentatively but amicably received. Like the small beaches that join the water and land, the Bonin Islands were a small but essential solder point between the U.S. and Japan, mediating communication between these two distant societies.
