http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Completed in early 1906, the Yokohama-Bonin cable was part of a system linking Japan and the United States, with stopovers on several Pacific islands. As the journal Telegraph Age reports that year: “Bonin has recently been connected to Yokohama by a cable of English manufacture which the Japanese government has been laying with its own cable-ship, the Okinawa Maru. . . . The work was finished in twelve days without the least hitch, and the signals through the cable when laid were excellent.”

“The view of the harbor in clear weather is beautiful and animated,” notes an 1897 travel guide to Surabaya. Under Dutch rule since 1743, it was the main commercial port and largest Dutch naval base in the East Indies. “On the water and along the quays great bustle prevails. . . . Chinese and Javanese, Europeans and Arabs, citizens and soldiers mingle” in the crowded streets. The arrival of two Dutch submarine cables in 1913 and 1921 brought the city into further contact with other settlements in the region. But Surabaya’s growth and vibrancy was interrupted by conflict in the 1940s. The city was captured by the Japanese and bombed by Allied forces in the Second World War. And in the 1945 Battle of Surabaya, Indonesian soldiers fought British troops for national independence. This history of profound struggle resonates with the name Surabaya, which some say derives from a mythical battle between two powerful creatures, a “sura” (shark) and a “baya” (crocodile).

Although it was a landing site for the 1997 Asia-Pacific Cable Network, Chao Samran, Phetchaburi never grew into a major cable hub. Later connections favored stations in the south, closer to Malaysia, Singapore, and Indonesia, or the economically dominant Satun across the Gulf of Thailand. A similar shift occurred a hundred years ago during the reign of King Rama VI. In 1918, the king built a royal summer residence on the shores of Phetchaburi province, renamed Hat Chao Samran or “Royal Leisure Beach.” For a few years, Chao Samran was a popular vacation spot among elites. But poor transportation and a lack of fresh water eventually led the king to demolish the residence and rebuild it further south where resources were more plentiful.

“CABLE SITUATION AT AMOY. MUCH DISCONTENT” reads the headline in a 1931 Singapore newspaper. “The prosperity of business in Amoy largely depends upon its rapid communications by cable to the South Seas,” the article explains, but telegrams “intended for Amoy are now relayed to Shanghai.” Service was disrupted when, a few days prior, Chinese officials shut down the Great Northern Telegraph Company office on Kulangsu Island, where a Danish cable stopped on its way from Hong Kong and Shanghai. This cable originally bypassed Amoy, but in 1873, the company added a branch to the city without Chinese permission and began profiting from the added traffic. When China took control of the Kulangsu-Amoy connection in 1931, it disrupted local businesses already heavily reliant on submarine telegraphy.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1902, as part of a wave of strategically and nationally driven cables in the early twentieth century, the French post and telegraph service laid a system between Tourane, in French Indochina, to Amoy, China.

Mukilteo, a Native-American name that has come to mean “good camping ground,” has long been a staging ground for circulation and exchange. It was in Mukilteo that 82 Native American leaders signed over large swathes of land to white settlers in the famous Port Elliot Treaty. And as Americans migrated westward, enterprises such as the Puget Mill Lumber Company cleared the land for them, shipping the region’s trees to ports around the world, as far away as Shanghai and Cape Town. Harbour Pointe, a part of Mukilteo once owned by a logging company, was sold to Standard Oil, which planned to use the land for a refinery. Although this plan never materialized, in the 1960s the company put forward a proposal for “Possession Shores,” a master-planned community that would provide, among other things, housing for workers in the world’s largest factory: Boeing’s airplane assembly lot, only a few miles away. After decades, the master-plan has been at least partially realized. The town has upscale homes, an expansive golf course, technology parks, and two undersea cable systems which can take you from the "camping ground" of Harbour Pointe to Alaska, California, and Japan.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: Harbour Pointe Pacific Crossing cable station doors

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: NTT

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Reihoku occupies a knob-shaped peninsula on the largest island of Amakusa, meaning “heaven’s grass” and named after its verdant, undulating terrain. Part of the underwater network only briefly, the town was linked to Nanhui by the East China Sea telephone cable between 1976 and 1997. Earlier telegraph lines to China surfaced in Nagasaki while Miyazaki received later fiber-optic connections. The cable’s landing site is similarly bracketed by historical and contemporary infrastructures. On one side are the ruins of Tomioka Castle, built in the early 1600s by a feudal lord and later attacked by rebelling Christian peasants. And on the other is a modern coal-fired power station that generates most of the electricity for the surrounding Kumamoto Prefecture.

The KDDI-owned East China Sea Cable, also know as the Japan-China cable system, linked Reihoku and Nanhui in 1976. A commemorative silver coin shows a dotted line across the East China Sea, bisected by a telephone receiver emitting bolts of electricity. Its 480-voice-channel capacity was interrupted in 1980 by fishing operations and not repaired until five years later. ECSC was eventually decommissioned in 1997.
Tags places 300-599 imported from the Telegeography data.

When the cable landed in 1859, Muntok was still a small town, with red-roofed houses clustered around a bay and tall, straight palm trees lining empty dirt roads. The engineer who installed the cable wrote of Muntok: “All serene. Great trouble with the telegraphists … who sleep on duty, and otherwise keep Siemens constantly in the station.” Yet after the 1860s, the area became critical to the circulation of goods around the world – Bangka, where Muntok was located, was one of Indonesia’s “tin isles.” By the turn of the century, these islands supplied two-thirds of the world’s tin, including much of the metal used in canning perishable food. One author observed: “Few other metals were so integral to the web of industrialization and mass consumption yet so reliant on trade from tropical territories.” Although indigenous and Chinese miners had long extracted the ore, the Dutch brought new mining techniques to the island, including hydraulic technologies capable of removing fifty cubic meters of soil per hour. Such practices devastated the landscape. Two-thirds of Bangka’s forest had been stripped by the 1920s, and its rivers filled with silt. Though much of the infrastructure of the colonial period, including the undersea cable, has disappeared, mining continues to ground the island’s economy. Muntok is home to the biggest tin smelter in the world, its landscape is scattered with craters, and its waters are polluted with heavy metals.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Famous for its fortifications more than its receptiveness, Taku has been a gateway to China since the 1500s. It is just downriver from the busy trading city of Tianjin, where the Hai connects to the Yellow and Yangtze rivers, and boats filled with goods have traveled for centuries. The water that connects Taku also made it vulnerable. To protect against Japanese pirates, the Chinese erected forts here in the 16th century. The forts were expanded during the Opium Wars of the 19th century, but in 1858 the British won a battle that opened the port to foreign trade, Christian missionaries, and the import of opium. In 1900, the Chinese government commissioned both the Great Northern Telegraph Company and the Eastern Extension Telegraph Company to lay cables to Taku. Things were tense: signals were often intercepted, foreign boats lurked in the harbor, Chinese troops filled the forts, and almost 2400 Russian soldiers were stationed in Tianjin. In June of that year, as the Boxer Rebellion erupted in Beijing, the occupying western nations collaboratively and successfully attacked the Taku Forts in a violent battle, leaving the area awash in “rivers of blood.” As was the case in many locales, cables followed conflict, and a month later, a German company began the construction on its own telegraph to Taku.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: An oil boom in the early 1900s transformed Balikpapan from a small fishing village into a center of petroleum production. It became the regional headquarters of the Bataafsche Petroleum Company in 1907, and tankers carrying petrol and paraffin wax soon filled the harbor. Balikpapan’s industrial success spurred investment in roads, buildings, and communications: this included three undersea cables set up by the Dutch East Indies Government and a high-powered wireless telegraph station that could transmit signals hundreds of miles to other colonial settlements. Cable and wireless telegraphy proved invaluable for coordinating petroleum shipping in the area. Oil merchants, explains a 1914 article, “call first at Balikpapan or at some other port in telegraphic communication with Balikpapan so that the latter is always advised by telegraph of the prospective sailings and calls and requirements of these tank boats.”

You find yourself in a dark, small stone building, in the company of a Japanese military man. Outside, things are quiet. A road lined with palm trees leads into the dark green mountains, overlooking shallow blue-green harbors. Boats are prohibited from anchoring here because of the cable. Midway between Taiwan and the main island of Okinawa, Ishigaki has recently become essential for Japanese international and military communications. In 1897, this building has been newly built to transmit telegraph signals to Okinawa and Taiwan. In years to come, the quiet will be shattered by wars. The building will become busy with transmissions, bombed, and damaged, although not destroyed. Long after it is abandoned, some locals will sense that ghosts remain inside.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: On the shore at Mon Repos, a group of sea turtle hatchlings makes their way across the sandy beach and into the ocean. Long before this beach became a conservation park for the now endangered turtles, the site was a landing for a French telegraph cable. It was a short-lived system, connecting the nearby municipality of Bundaberg with the French colony of New Caledonia. At that time, Bundaberg and its environs were hardly developed. The area was populated by a small group of European timbergetters and farmers, and an established indigenous population of Kabi people, from whose language the city derives its name. A sawmill was built along the municipality’s river in 1868, drawing surveyors and settlers, and a sugar mill was built in 1882, around which a successful industry grew. This small, industrial, mostly British town had little interest in New Caledonia, a French colony known mostly for its political prisoners and fledgling mining industry.

Malacca was an ancient fishing village before it was taken over by the Portuguese in the 1500s, followed by the Dutch and the British. When first telegraph cable arrived in 1879, the port city had both native and colonial populations, and each responded differently to the new technology. According to the British news report from Malacca, the local Malays avoided the cable house after dark, “even now when they see [that] no demon is concealed in the coil of wire.” For Malacca’s European inhabitants, however, the telegraph link was more mundane than mysterious. “One would have thought,” the article laments, “that the laying of the cable would have brought us more into communication with Singapore . . . that the wants of our little Settlement and more news about us would have appeared in the Journals but such is not the case.” Although the settlers did not feel fully connected, the cable had at least one practical benefit: “we get the time more exact than we used to.”

The small fishing village of Budai, Taiwan (known as Hotei in Japanese) played an important role in Japan’s conquest of Taiwan due to its proximity to the Penghu Islands. On the morning of October 10, 1895, Japanese military forces departed from their base on Penghu and sailed to Budai. From there, they moved south to encircle the capital city of Tainan. This connection was retraced more than two decades later by an undersea cable between Budai and Penghu, part of the expansion of Taiwan’s telegraph network under Japanese rule. In addition to its ties to military and communications networks, Budai was a regional hub of salt production in the early twentieth century. The city’s seawater evaporation plant employed several hundred workers and produced roughly eighteen million pounds of salt per year.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Waves crash up against a thick seawall that spans the coast of Toucheng. Much of the shore here in northeast Taiwan is comprised of sand rock, eroded by ocean waves and monsoon winds. Some locals think these spectacular rock formations resemble tofu. Yet the erosion here is not entirely natural. The presence of manmade structures on 56% of Taiwan’s coast, this seawall included, has sped up the disappearance of its beaches. These structures interrupt the flow of sand, causing it to accumulate on one side and to quickly erode on the other. The nearby Toucheng beach, which once stretched for two kilometers, is now severely diminished, and the coast has retreated up to 100 meters inland. This seawall keeps the shoreline intact for both waves and cable stations, but provides an additional challenge for cable laying. Companies have to bore a hole through the thick walls in order to thread their networks through.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1887, a cable was laid from Anping harbor in Tainan, then the capital of Taiwan, to the Penghu archipelago on the order of Liu Mingchuan, an official in the Qing dynasty. The lack of trade between Tainan and Penghu meant that the cable “was of little importance to the commercial world,” explains American diplomat James W. Davidson. Yet “it was of great value from a political standpoint, the strategic importance of the [Penghu] islands demanding that they should be in communication with the capital.” This political value was short-lived, however, since the capital was moved north to Taipei later that year. Tainan has seen many such political fluctuations in its history. The Dutch established a fort here in the early 1600s, which was later taken over by Chinese military leaders, the Qing, the Japanese, and finally the Republic of China. Reconstituted under each new ruler, Tainen was nicknamed “The Phoenix City.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1893, during an autumn stay in Hawai’i, Robert Louis Stevenson wrote an advertisement for the local news paper: “If anyone desire such old-fashioned things as lovely scenery, quiet, pure air, clear sea water, good food, and heavenly sunsets hung out before his eyes over the Pacific and the distant hills of Waianae, I recommend him cordially to the ‘Sans Souci.’” A decade later, much had changed: the Hawaiian islands had been annexed by the United States and a telegraph cable was strung ashore at Sans Souci beach, connecting Hawai’i to Midway Island. With the completion of this cable, President Teddy Roosevelt sent a round-the-world telegram congratulating the cable’s projector, Mackay, from his home on Long Island to New York City via the Commerical Pacific Cable’s transoceanic link. The message took only twelve minutes. Little remains of this history at Sans Souci today, the only indication of the cable is a brief mention at the bottom of the menu at a local restaurant.

The port of Yokohama was a modest fishing village until the 1850s, when it was opened to foreign trade under pressure from the United States. Rapid development followed, transforming Yokohama into an international center of commerce. Japan’s first overland telegraph line linked Yokohama’s Court House station with neighboring Tokyo in 1869. Thirty-five years later, a submarine cable arrived from the Bonin Islands, bringing the city into communication with San Francisco more than 5,000 miles away. But the Great Kantō earthquake of 1923 devastated the city, including its nascent cable infrastructure. As a local newspaper reports, a tsunami swallowed boats in the harbor, fires swept through the streets, and “the telegraph building, in which most of the wires radiating to all parts of the island terminated, was completely demolished, leaving the telegraph system in a hopeless condition.” Yokohama was soon rebuilt, only to suffer more damage during the air raids of World War II.

From a mostly undeveloped beach several miles north of Miyazaki, you follow a dirt path inland until it opens onto a single-lane road. In the distance, a ringed communications tower is visible above the treetops. Homing in on this beacon, you reach a windowless building surrounded on all sides by a barbed-wire fence. Three majestic palm trees and a plaque bearing the logo of Japanese telecom company KDDI mark the entrance, while farmland and greenhouses occupy the surrounding plots. In 1977, the first telephone cable arrived from Okinawa, where a trans-Pacific link to the U.S. had recently been completed. Optical cables followed in the 1990s, but more recent connections have overlooked Miyazaki in favor of the cluster of hubs along the east coast of Honshu Island.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: China-Japan Fiber Optic Sea Cable (C-J FOSC)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: C-J FOSC, laid in 1993 for $70 million dollars, was the first fiber-optic undersea system connecting mainland China to the rest of the world. From its landing point in Miyazaki, Japan, it linked outward to much of Southeast Asia. Although this gave China connectivity, it made the nation highly dependent on one Japanese hub.

Arriving from the Southern Cross Cable Network, you surface on Narrabeen Beach, unhindered by fishing nets, boat anchors, or dredging equipment. These activities are prohibited in this government-sanctioned cable protection area, one of two established in Sydney in 2005. Once ashore, you travel four miles south to Brookvale, which has been a commercial and industrial center in North Sydney since the 1950s. The station blends in with surrounding businesses: sign printers, auto body shops, and several well-known surfboard manufacturers. As dents are repaired and signals enter local networks, many of the boards crafted in Brookvale end up back in the waves off Narrabeen Beach where volunteer lifeguards operate out of local surf clubs. This safe-zone for surfers and cables is the only Australian site mentioned in the 1963 Beach Boys hit “Surfin’ U.S.A.”

Founded in the fifteenth century by Muslim sultans, Aceh (then Kutaraja or “City of the King”) was a prosperous trade port – it delivered over half the world’s pepper supply in the 1820s. Yet the city’s status as a commercial hub is overshadowed by a history of war and natural disaster. Between 1873 and 1903, the Dutch fought local Acehnese forces for control of Northern Sumatra. In the midst of the long and bloody conflict, Dutch ships laid a cable to their settlement in Medan to aid military communications. A century later, an earthquake struck off the west coast of Aceh, causing a devastating tsunami that killed tens of thousands and leveled large swaths of the city. Although there were no warning systems in place in 2004, new research suggests that undersea cables could one day be used to track the waves and signal evacuations.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:
Robert Cribb and Audrey Kahin. Historical Dictionary of Indonesia (Second Edition). Lanham, MD: Scarecrow Press, 2004. 3-6.
Robert Cribb. Historical Atlas of Indonesia. Surrey: Curzon, 2000. 115-6.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1991, North Pacific Cable built a brand new station on the remote Oregon coast. Established far from the AT&T landing in Bandon, this building pioneered cable landing in northern Oregon, now a critical gateway for Internet traffic entering and leaving the country. Even though it paved the way for development, North Pacific Cable was eventually made obsolete by these newer links, and with this, the station was shut down. It was not until years afterward that Tillamook Lightwave purchased the station in order to expand regional access to the network. Part of the station was leased to the University of Washington for their Regional Scale Nodes project, an ocean cable system that lets scientists observe deep-sea life forms and processes. A building constructed merely to funnel signals through the area now links the many populations, human and non-human, on the Oregon coast.

When it opened in 1991, the North Pacific Cable was the highest-capacity system to link Japan and North America. “This pioneering effort helps usher in what futurists . . . call the fibersphere,” declared the president of Pacific Telecom, the cable’s U.S. sponsor. The following year, Tokyo Broadcasting System sent high-definition television signals between Miura and Pacific City to demonstrate the “Advantages of terrestrial fiber transmission” over satellite, including “high bandwidth, high reliability and less delay.”

Fukuoka has been an exchange point between Japan and the rest of Asia for millennia. In the year 57, a Han Dynasty emperor bestowed a gold seal on the King of Na (present day Fukuoka). Over the following centuries, the city’s proximity to Korea and China facilitated international trade as well as the flow of Buddhism and agricultural techniques into Japan. But this proximity also made it a target: Fukuoka was attacked by Mongol fleets in the 1200s, only to be saved by well-timed typhoons or “kamikazes” (Japanese for “divine wind”). Communication technologies only reinforced these ancient economic, cultural, and military connections. Telegraph cables linked the Kyushu region with Korea beginning in the 1880s, radiotelephone was introduced in the 1920s, and the arrival of a submarine cable in 1937 provided long-distance telephone service between Japan, Korea, and China for the first time.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Kyushu Electric Power,  KT,  Softbank Telecom,  NTT

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Traveling across clear blue waters and through mushroom-shaped rock islands, you reach the shores of Palau. Beneath a pristine landscape often imaged in tourism magazines lies a modern history of struggles between nations. Although inhabited for millennia without interference, Palau’s strategic position in the North Pacific drew competing territorial claims in the late 1800s from Britain, Spain, and Germany. After a period of Spanish rule, the fertile islands were sold to the Germans who began exploiting their natural resources. Japan annexed Palau in 1914, established a regional government headquarters, promoted large-scale immigration, and built fish canneries and coconut processing plants. The town of Koror, Palau’s capital, was once known as “Little Tokyo,” a nod to the strong Japanese presence in this period. During World War II, a German telegraph cable was redirected to Palau to strengthen communication links to Japan. And in 1944, Japanese and American forces clashed in the months-long Battle of Peleliu with heavy casualties on both sides. Although Palau finally became an independent state in 1994, in many ways it remains dependent on the infrastructure and currency of other nations.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Gordon L. Rottman, World War II Pacific Island Guide: A Geo-Military Study. Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: When they set up their cable station in Cromer, Australia, the PIPE International team decided to take a new approach to the surrounding public. Instead of hiding the network’s development, they started a blog where they posted photos of the cable’s installation, the equipment they used, and the operators’ activities. One engineer recounts that they tried to do community outreach as well. At one point they hosted a barbeque and asked residents to come see why the company had occupied their park for several months. As he described: “a lot of PR went into it to make sure the objections and problems were minimized.” Unlike most fiber-optic systems, PIPE made the cable laying “a social event.” The company's efforts have paid off. Not only did their outreach efforts generate publicity for their network, but they have had few problems with the local community since they began operation.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Pipe Networks

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Deep Water Bay cable station is situated on one of the most expensive properties in our undersea network. Overlooking a small bay on Hong Kong’s south shore, the station was built when there was little development in the area. Today, it is the oldest still operational station on the island and has been the connection point for numerous cables since the 1960s. In the intervening years, Hong Kong’s affluent residents migrated to the nearby hills and the area’s forest was replaced with mansions. Unlike the typical windowless structures that populate the cable system, Deep Water Bay’s postwar architecture offers a lookout onto the beaches and ocean below. Peering out of the station windows, you have a better view of the bay than Hong Kong’s richest man. There are few people here to enjoy it, however: since it opened, machines have replaced many of the workers.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Known as the “River City,” Banjarmasin is situated at the intersection of the Martapura and Barito rivers on Borneo’s southern coast. In the seventeenth century, the country’s rich natural resources—including gold, pepper, and gambier (a plant with medicinal properties)—were transported by river and sold in the natural harbor to Chinese, British, and Dutch traders. Native craftsmen were famous for their flat-bottomed wooden vessels, which carried goods through the city’s network of canals. After they secured a trade monopoly, the Dutch made Banjarmasin the capital of Borneo in the late 1700s. Soon thereafter, the electrical flows of telegraph communication joined the liquid and trade flows that defined the city’s pre-colonial history.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Situated in an office park, the Alexandria cable station is just a few hundred feet from the Alexandra Canal, built in the late nineteenth century to provide barge access to South Sydney. By the 1940s, Alexandria had more than five hundred factories producing bricks, wool fabrics, airplane parts, and other goods, as well as a branch of the Standard Telephones and Cables Company. Set up to provide voice links to Britain in the early twentieth century, Standard went on to manufacture underwater cables, including one between Sydney and Vancouver in the 1980s. Despite its proximity to the station, cables don’t surface in the canal, now widely considered the most polluted waterway in Australia. Instead, lines from the Southern Cross system arrive near the historical cable landing at Bondi Beach before heading inland to Alexandria. Here, connections are made to several nearby data centers, drawn to the area by the presence of the cable head.

When China began to struggle against imperialism in the late 1800s, Qingdao was an important node of resistance. The Boxers, an anti-imperialist, proto-nationalist Chinese movement, had a strong presence in area, and in 1897, the Chinese government began building up a military base here to protect against foreign invasion. Shortly thereafter, German troops seized and occupied this fort. After a year of fighting, China conceded the area to Germany, who re-named the city Tsingtau, a French transliteration of the original name. This small Chinese fishing village was transformed into a German administrative and economic center, with tall three-story stone buildings, wide streets, electricity, and a navy base. At the turn of the century, two telegraph cables were landed, one connecting to Tschifu and one to Shanghai. Today, two major cable systems continue to land at Qingdao, linking the city to Korea and across the sea to California.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Following a link from Nagasaki to Tsingtau, the Japanese Military laid a cable between Tsingtau to Sasebo, where their naval base was located.

Marco Polo stopped at the remote islands of Poulo Condor (now known as Con Dao) on his way from China to India, later writing “there is nothing about them worth mentioning.” Yet the archipelago’s remoteness and nondescript character made it an ideal setting for more than a century of incarceration. After taking control of Poulo Condor in 1787, the French constructed a 120-cell prison to hold opponents of the colonial government, including many high-ranking Vietnamese military leaders. While prisoners were detained, French signals flowed freely through the island’s telegraph station. The prison was later turned over to the South Vietnamese and became the site of the notorious “tiger cages,” maintained by the U.S. during the Vietnam War. This isolated island became globally visible when a 1970 issue of Life magazine revealed the prison’s inhumane conditions.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Sasebo became an essential node for military communications at the turn of the twentieth century. This Japanese port is about 100 miles south of the southern tip of Korea, across the ocean from Shanghai. The town had been a small fishing village until the Meiji Period, when it quickly became an important naval base because of its protected, nearly land-locked, deep harbor. In 1898, a major railway station was opened here, anticipating the other traffic to come. Cables came in from Port Arthur, and out across the East China Sea to Dairen and Tsingtau. The town grew up around the transiting traffic, becoming a busy port and a wireless station. Like many other hubs in the Pacific, its connectivity would become a liability in future years. The wireless station here is believed to have broadcasted the message to attack Pearl Harbor during World War II. Four years later, Sasebo suffered severe bombing by allied forces, and was on the list of potential targets for the dropping of the atom bomb.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Portuguese, Spanish, and Dutch forces vied with local rulers for control of this small volcanic island, the northern gateway to the “spice islands” of Maluku and once the world’s only source of cloves. In the 1600s, the Dutch seized Ternate and began to manage trade in the region. The East India Company created a monopoly on cloves by destroying all non-Dutch plantations and making unauthorized growing punishable by death. Trade expansion necessitated faster communication channels, and in 1913 an underwater cable connected Ternate to Dutch settlements in Java and Borneo. As clove production spread elsewhere, the island became less centrally important. But a nearly 400-year-old clove tree—the oldest in the world—still stands on Ternate as evidence of its past distinctiveness.

The island of Iki, along with its neighbor Tsushima, “form the stepping-stones between Japan and Korea,” explains a 1912 reference book. For centuries, Iki was an intermediate safe harbor for merchant and pirate ships passing through the Genkai Sea. And in the early 1900s, the island became a stepping-stone for cables. By 1920, seven telegraph cables had landed near the southwestern port town of Gōnoura, which sits at the base of an inactive volcano and is surrounded by rice fields. Four of these lines ran to the main Japanese islands and three to Tsushima, where additional cables carried messages the rest of the way to Busan. When a telephone line was installed in 1937, Iki became a stepping-stone for voice signals on their journey across the Korean Strait.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The volcanic island of Jeju, meaning “province across the sea,” sits sixty miles off the coast of South Korea. Before the island became more closely linked to the mainland by tourism and underwater cables, it had a distinct language, culture, and ocean-based economy. Female free divers known as “haenyeo,” or “sea women,” have gathered shellfish and other marine life from the Korea Strait for generations, though their numbers are dwindling. In the 1990s, Jeju became a landing site for undersea electrical and communication lines. A branch of the Hong Kong-Japan-Korea (HJK) system surfaced on Jeju's shores in 1990, and in 1996, a high-voltage cable joined the island’s power grid to the Korean Peninsula. With the decommissioning of HJK, Jeju fell out of the international cable circuit, redirecting all signal traffic through mainland hubs.

“The trees obscure the houses near the beach, making it difficult to distinguish the port,” warns a British steamship captain in 1910. His description of Buleleng also notes the twin telegraph cables connecting the town to other Dutch colonies across the Bali Sea and to the nearby island province of West Nusa Teggara. In the 1840s, the Dutch performed a series of military operations in northern Bali before establishing a formal colony in Buleleng in 1882. It was their first on the island and the center of the new colonial administration. Although camouflaged by trees, the Buleleng harbor was a highly visible point on the map of international trade. By the late nineteenth century, dozens of European ships and hundreds of local vessels carrying rice, coffee, spices, vanilla, and tobacco came through the port every year.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: A 1903 guidebook describes the bay of Kwandang as “beautiful and picturesque” but also “abandoned” and “densely covered with vegetation.” There is “scarcely a house or sign of cultivation . . . to be seen anywhere in the midst of the primeval wood.” The town is located inland from the port and is largely invisible through the foliage. Although secluded, “the neatness of the roads and houses proves that Kwandang is not a self-governed country, but under Dutch Government.” The Portuguese arrived in the 1500s and built a stone fort to defend the region from pirates. A century later, the Dutch took possession of the island-filled bay, one of the best natural harbors in northern Sulawesi. In 1903, they linked it by submarine cable to Balikpapan and Menado. Despite clear signs of development, however, Kwandang remained a wild place. A gang of pirates besieged the colony in the late 1800s until Dutch ships finally “came to the rescue from Ternate.”

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: For a relatively brief period between 1980 and 1997, you could travel here from Pusan along a coaxial cable under the Korea Strait. Emerging on a white-sand beach, you’d find one of the largest deep-sea trade ports in western Japan, abuzz with ships carrying local fish, seaweed, and wood products. The town formed around a hilltop castle built in 1620 and later destroyed by its creators to prevent it from falling into enemy hands. Hamada’s cable station was also abandoned and dismantled, but for a different reason: new fiber-optic networks offered faster connections between Japan and Korea via hubs closer to Tokyo-Yokohama. While the castle ruins, including a stone foundation and wooden gateway, are now a popular tourist attraction that reminds visitors of the city’s long history, evidence of its place in the underwater network has all but disappeared.
Completed in 1980 by Japan’s KDDI Corporation, this coaxial system linked Hamada and Pusan. It was decommissioned in 1997 and donated to the Ocean Research Institute at Tokyo University.

The Indian Ocean has long been a pivotal site of passage, conquest, and exchange between Asia and Africa. Since the time of the Egyptian Pharaohs, empires and merchants alike have charted its waters in pursuit of resources and trade. Europe, separated from the ocean by the bulk of Africa, was relatively late to establish a presence in the region. However, when it finally did this introduction spurred technological and cultural transformations of a markedly disruptive and violent nature, setting into motion an international network of colonies, slave migrations, and commodity supply chains. Such interconnections were intensified by communications systems under the ocean. Gutta-percha, a latex resin sourced from the Malay Peninsula on the edge of the Indian Ocean, insulated early transoceanic cables and accelerated colonial transport and exploitation. Coaxial and fiber-optic networks followed, again allowing for agile industrial and political dispatches between nations otherwise polarized by international wars and economic inequalities. Today, regional governments in Africa and South Asia have more say in network development than ever before, and cable systems are bringing about new economic and political alignments.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: No international communications cables land in Baltimore, but this maritime city is a hub of international cabling. TE Subcom – a company that manufactures, lays, and repairs a significant portion of the world’s undersea cables  – is based here. Giant cable ships are docked next to their harbor-side warehouse. Spools of cable remain nestled below deck. These ships can lay cable across an entire ocean, retrieve a line from the bottom of the seabed, and repair systems in mid-ocean. Given how complex and expensive they are, cable ships are far and few between, making the cable repair industry reliant on companies such as TE Subcom.
